reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Hitman: Absolution‚Ñ¢
Original Release: 2012
Genre Tags: Stealth; Action; Third-Person; Shooter
My Overall Grade: A-
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 15-25 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: Auxiliary
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Fans of the intellectual property; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs
REVIEWI‚Äôm going to start off by saying that I thought this was a great, high-quality game.  I really enjoyed the high-production-value inherent in all of the facets of the game.  The graphics were crisp, the controls were smooth, the writing was interesting, the acting was excellent, etc.  This is a high-quality game, period.

Moving on from there, I also personally felt that the game was extremely fun and that it does a great job of appealing to a wide audience (which, whether you personally like it or not, is the goal of any developers/publishers).  Now I understand that some people felt let down by this game after they had greatly enjoyed previous installments in the franchise.  They didn‚Äôt like some of the directions the developers chose to go with Hitman: Absolution‚Ñ¢ and thus formed a very vocal group of disappointed customers.  If you are among these people, then I‚Äôm sure nothing I can say will sway your opinion, and that is fine.  It is impossible to please everyone, and the developers did their best to appeal to as many people as possible when they made this game.

In my opinion, disregarding how it stacks up against its predecessors and strictly looking at the game as its own entity, I can whole-heartedly say: I think this game is extremely fun.  Most gamers should be able to find a way to enjoy playing this game.  If you only want to play through on easy and enjoy the AAA quality story and cinematics, you can do that.  If you want to be frustrated with extreme difficulty and be challenged to your maximum breaking point, you can do that.  If you want to replay levels to explore different paths and collect hundreds of in-game achievements, you can do that.  And of course, if you want to fall somewhere in between those extremes, you can most certainly do that.

One thing I will admit I was not a fan of was the checkpoint system, or lack thereof.  Trying to experiment with various ways to complete levels can quickly go from fun to frustrating when you realize you have to start the level from the beginning every time you mess up.  I personally feel having a quick-save option would have been nice and would have allowed an even more widely varied audience to be able to enjoy the game.  Those who don‚Äôt want to play with quick-saves could just simply not use it, or they could have made it unavailable in the top difficulties, but still allowed it in the ‚Äúnormal‚Äù difficulty.  But, having said all that, most levels can be beaten in less than 5 minutes, so having to start from the top isn‚Äôt that awful‚Ä¶ and it does prevent the game from becoming, maybe, too easy.  I still will always prefer having the choice to decide for myself if I want to use quick-saves in a game, or challenge myself not to.

To put it shortly: Hitman: Absolution‚Ñ¢ is an extremely fun game with a noticeably high-production-value quality about it.  It is certainly different from previous games in the franchise, and in some people‚Äôs opinions it is not as good as previous games in the franchise; but regardless of whether or not you agree with those people, the game itself is still a good game.  Most gamers will able to find this game enjoyable by customizing the experience to their preferences.

reviewText:
It‚Äôs been a long time since a game has absolutely infuriated me. Hitman: Absolution manages to do it.

This is going to be a pretty long rant/review, so be prepared.

Disclaimer: Played 20 hours campaign, on Hard.

I‚Äôll start straight off with the main problem: The Disguise System changes. In Blood Money, enemies
would treat you differently based on what disguise you had on; each disguise had different ‚Äúpermissions‚Äù, in terms of what areas of the map you can go in. Enemies would never see through your disguise unless you acted strangely (carried guns as a waiter, throwing objects, bumping into people while sprinting).In Absolution, enemies with the same disguise as you will start pursuing you if you stand in their  vision too long (which is a very short time limit). After this, it‚Äôs only a matter of time until they  realize you‚Äôre not really who your disguise says you are and start opening fire. This prompts everyone to start shooting you. Add in the fact that maps typically are CRAWLING with guards of the same uniform and disguises have little worth the majority of the time.

My primary tactic in response to these changes was to change disguise to something beyond a typical cop/guard so I would not be noticed. Sometimes this worked, sometimes I got noticed by other janitors/ushers/etc of the same kind. The only difference of being caught by these guys is that they run away and tell the nearest guards to start shooting you instead. Later levels had high saturation of many types of NPCs, which made me hop from disguise to disguise.

Why is this problem in need of such detail? I found that it forced me to 1) pacify/kill more NPCs than I wanted to and 2) always be looking at patrolling NPCs instead of my enviornment, which is even worse as my first concern on my first playthrough was to look around the map and find what options I had to killing my target. I spent less time planning my kills and more times trying to avoid a massive shootout.

While Hard difficulty increases both the number of enemies and how fast they respond, I feel that
easier difficulties only reduce the above problems in terms of scale. Fundamentally, I found
the disguise and detection mechanics to be absolutely infuriating. I can‚Äôt count how many times
I restarted a checkpoint when an npc turned a corner and unveiled me (proximity decreases how much time you have until detection), and unless you deal with who detected you within 1 second, other enemies will be alerted and sometimes even call for backup! It causes a messy, compounding situation that made me just restart the mission every time I was spotted.

This problem reaches its apex in the later half of the game, where almost every enviornment is small and populated with a variety of npcs. Preventing detection required me to burn Instinct and keep behind small cover the whole time. Like mentioned above, this prevented me from exploring (and this getting a good feel for) the missions, making me feel restricted in what should be a sandbox scenario.

I‚Äôll be honest and say I have not finished the game. I‚Äôm in the middle of the epilogue mission, but after
going through the first half of it just gunning down everyone (including my target), I realized that I
didn‚Äôt care anymore. I‚Äôm going to uninstall this game after posting this review.

I know I haven‚Äôt mentioned the story, Contracts mode, or even any of the other mechanics yet. To
keep things sparse:

+the story is interesting enough to want to see what happens next, although 47‚Äôs character motivations are a little arbitrary. I found the main villian to be entertainingly nutty and even a bit threatening.

+shooting and cover mechanics are solid. Aiming feels fine and you can choose whether you want 47 to ‚Äústick‚Äù to cover or not.

+Contracts is an interesting idea, but the majority of levels in this game are linear, and I found the sandbox levels to not be fun for the reasons already stated.

I really hate to say that I got so frustrated with a game. I hate being yet another person on the internet saying I didn‚Äôt have fun with a game, although I hope I have clearly expressed why I felt that way. Perhaps other people will find this game more fun than I did. However, I strongly advise watching some videos on it, even parts of a playthrough before you make your purchase.

reviewText:
Absolution draws a hard line between itself and the previous 4 installments of the game without alienating die hard fans of this franchise. Absolution is far more cerebral than it's predecessors. The storyline is multifaceted and weaves together a plot that focuses on exposing 47's ambitions, strengths, and flaws without making him appear weak or whiny; he is still the ultimate badass, but much more human and believable. Absolution shows a more realistic and approachable 47; one I, and I assume others, can easily identify with. This game really develops Hitman's character on a much deeper level than previously attempted.

The movements of 47 are very swift and responsive. In fact, many of 47's movements can be compared to how Sam Fisher's movements are in the Splinter Cell games, which means players can now access cover and look around at a 360 angle. I would also compare the sneaking around to the Metal Gear games, as well. In this game, there are just SO many ways to go about taking out a primary target. On one level, I was given the option to take out a target in 12 different ways. That way could be by taking him out, wearing various disguises, taken him out quietly, poisoning his food, blowing his car up or taking him out with guns blazing. Not to mention, players can get reward for doing so, which enhances the replay value of this game.

The AI has been greatly improved. Characters interact with their environment, situations, and the actions of 47 in many fascinating ways now. Characters generally still have predetermined paths but they can now be interrupted, altered, redirected, and distracted to allow 47 to accomplish his objectives. This really makes a difference in the game play. You no longer have to memorize guards paths or actions, rather you can now change the course of events by affecting the characters in any given situation to gain access to your targets.

All in all this game is by far the best adaptation of Hitman yet. I highly recommend it. You can play this game and still feel comfortable without having ever played any previous versions.

reviewText:
Hitman: Absolution is a stealth game, developed by IO Interactive and published by Square Enix. This instalment is the 5th game in the Hitman series. The game was released on November 20th 2012; ironically this is the 47th week of the year, referencing the main character Agent 47.

As with the rest of the Hitman series, you play from a third person perspective. You play as Agent 47 who is the best hitman around. Gameplay is very similar to the previous games, with a strong focus on stealthy progression on every level. At points there will be times where a gun fight will break out, but that usually means you are either very close to the end of the mission or have chosen the path of a deadly mercenary and just going all guns blazing anyway.  Each mission has multiple ways of completing it; you can actually finish the whole game by not shooting anyone, you can set up scenarios so that your ‚Äútargets‚Äù die in an ‚Äúunfortunate‚Äù accident or poisoning.  One of the major changes to Absolution is that Agent 47 now has an ‚ÄúInstinct‚Äù ability ‚Äì this allows you to  track enemies more, and shows up interactable objects more easily. This of course has a limited supply but will slowly regenerate over the course of the mission. The stealth side of the game is done very well, and has the right amount of challenge for you to not get stumped with not being able to progress, but not so easy that you can do it blind folded.  The ability to pick up objects around the world and throw them into enemies path‚Äôs to distract them is always a good addition to a stealth game; but also sabotaging items such as electrics to also cause a distraction. The main aim of most of the missions is to take out a target, whilst causing as little disruption as possible, you are scored at the end of each mission taking into consideration how many ‚Äúnon-targets‚Äù were killed and other variables.

Graphically, Absolution is stunning.  So much so that the actual gameplay looks better than the cut-scenes. The animations are perfect both in game and in the cut scenes too; it looks like you are playing a film at times. On top of the gorgeous graphics, the sound effects and voice acting are all perfectly spot on.

Sadly this game is not as challenging as previous games; this was done to bring in a broader audience to the franchise. You can play the game on a fair few levels of difficulty; hard-core fans of the series will need to be playing this on the harder difficulties. You can always make the game even harder by playing through the game in a complete stealth style.

All of the Absolution‚Äôs missions are huge and extremely well designed. Each of them has more than two ways of completing the objective, on each level there will also be evidence that you can destroy, this will grant you more points at the end of the stage by doing so.  The levels have plenty of buildings, and rooms to explore and you‚Äôll spend most of the time hiding in them to be fair!

The game is very an extremely good length; it took me just under 28 hours to complete, this was mainly because I tried to complete each level as stealthy as possible, but even then, twenty eight hours for any game is long! There is also a huge amount of replay ability in the game too; not only can you replay the story mode on different difficulties and trying out different methods of taking out your targets, but there is also the ‚ÄúChallenge Mode‚Äù, which is player made missions giving an almost infinite amount of gameplay for you to play through.

I had no technical problems with Absolution, I wasn‚Äôt able to push the game out on 4k resolutions, simply because it dropped my frame rate below 60, but that is because the graphics would have been mind-boggling. The game can be played with a controller, but I would suggest playing it on keyboard and mouse as you may need quite a bit of precision when it comes to planning your attacks. The game also has plenty of graphical options which are always nice to see; a field of view option would have been nice though.

To sum up, Hitman Absolution is in my opinion one of the best Hitman games; nothing will ever come close to being better than Contracts, but this one is easily second to that. The game‚Äôs gorgeous graphics, stellar gameplay and Hollywood like plot easily makes this one of the best games of from recent years.  The regular price of ¬£14, 99 is very fair for this game too; however it is pretty much always on sale, so wait for the reduction if you can!

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

reviewText:
The Hitman series has continually challenged players with tracking and assassinating various targets across the world, while providing multiple routes in which to accomplish the particular tasks at hand. Absolution marks the first true entry in the current generation of games built upon its powerful, in-house built Glacier 2 graphics engine. In addition, the gameplay has been altered with the introduction of new features associated with the Instinct and Contracts modes.

Set directly after the events of the previous game, Hitman: Blood Money, Absolution tasks Agent 47 with tracking down his series handler Diana Burnwood after she goes rogue and reveals the agency's identity to the public. The new Agency director Benjamin Travis orders Agent 47 to kill Diana and capture a teenage girl by the name of Victoria that has been under her care. Upon reading a letter left from Diana, the narrative spirals into a chaotic set of events interwoven with Agent 47 being hunted by both the police and a cast of villains that aim to capture the mysterious Victoria from him. The majority of levels are set in various exterior and interior locales in Chicago and a small town in South Dakota.

A major contrast from past games in the series is the addition of entire level sequences that focus on evading the police while reaching a designated exit. In these particular sequences, players aren't even provided with particular targets to assassinate that results in the gameplay resembling a generic shooter versus a Hitman game. Some sections feel eerily similar to the gameplay of IO Interactive's past Kane and Lynch series of games. The levels that do offer particular targets to assassinate and multiple routes in which to accomplish that task are the most memorable of the narrative and beg for multiple playthroughs.

Each playthrough of a level is continually scored based on each action taken by the player from killing civilians to being detected by patrolling enemies. The game has a way in which it wants the player to complete each level and any deviations result in the loss of points. Compared with recent games in the Hitman series, Absolution includes far too many linear paths and evade the police scenarios that result in an overall more restrictive experience.

The major change in the Hitman gameplay formula in Absolution revolves around the addition of the Instinct mode. Instinct in the game is displayed through a meter that regenerates overtime through various actions taken. There are a variety of uses that involve Instinct mode from scanning the environment for enemies and their movement, which is similar to the detective mode in Batman Arkham Asylum, to a quick shot kill system, which is similar to the mark and execute feature in Splinter Cell: Conviction. While both are not original concepts, they work exceptionally well in surveying the environment and when in difficult situations that require a quick takedown of multiple enemies.

The major aspect of Instinct mode that will cause some frustration with players is how it handles disguises. NPCs in the game can detect that the player is lying about their identity if wearing the same disguise, with the example that other police officers would be able to spot someone new in their ranks. To counter this, Agent 47 can either wear disguises that aren't of the same group of NPCs or use Instinct mode to hide their true identity. Unfortunately, Instinct mode when used for disguises drains at an alarmingly quick rate that makes it useful for only brief scenarios. In later levels, disguises feel completely useless when nearly all of the NPCs are of the same group and can quickly discover Agent 47.

Aside from the new Instinct mode and cover system, nearly all of the Hitman series basics return with the infamous fiber wire and dual Silverballer pistols. Along with a host of other weaponry from pistols and shotguns to rifles and explosives, Agent 47 has the ability to utilize various weapons and staged accidents located throughout levels. Makeshift weapons appear in the form of small objects like knives, hammers, and even bongs. While some of them aren't the most practical to use in combat situations, they serve as great alternatives to when a more specialized approach is required for a certain situation.

Following with the tradition of past games in the series, Agent 47 has the ability to utilize conveniently-placed staged accidents around the level that range from a hoisted car on a lift to food items that are ripe for poisoning. While some staged accidents are simple to put in motion, others require carefully-planned timing and execution to perform the perfect assassination. Absolution stays true to the Hitman series by continually providing players with a near endless amount of options in assassinating targets from going completely Rambo style to a more subtle approach with a knife stab in the back.

Levels completed in the campaign mode can later be played through in the Contracts mode that has players setting their own targets and selecting loadouts of unlocked disguises/weapons. The points earned in the both modes can be used to unlock additional disguises, weapons, and gun modifications ranging from silencers to extended clips. Contracts mode introduces the Hitman series first online feature in that the scenarios that players devise can be uploaded online for others to download and play. When creating a custom contract, players walk through a level and assassinate whom they wish and with what disguise and weapon they feel is right for the particular task. When the target eliminated, players then rush to an exit point to complete the level. With the level complete and statistics tracked for the time taken for both assassinating the target and reaching the exit, players can then proceed with uploading the contract for other players to compete in beating their score. Players that use the particular disguise and weapon that the creator did in their original playthrough will earn additional points when completing the contract.

Contracts mode seems to be the developer's answer to the restrictive campaign levels and escape from the police sections. The Contracts mode is clearly not the perfect solution for fans that were looking for similar gameplay from the previous Hitman game, but it's a step in the right direction considering that players can select their own disguise and weapon loadout. Contracts mode will be interesting to watch as more players upload their specialized combination of levels, targets, disguises, and weapon loadouts.

IO Interactive's Glacier 2 engine can be summarized with 1 word: stunning. From the massively-rendered crowds to the detailed interior/exterior environments, Absolution never ceases to amaze with visuals that beg to be set to max. Absolution debuts as the first real entry of the Hitman series in the high-definition era of gaming and succeeds at trumping nearly all of the current game releases. The sound effects and most notably the music succeed at impressing with loud and bold gunfire and mesmerizing classical scores. The soundtrack composed by Thomas B√§rtschi fits the atmosphere of Absolution perfectly whether it may be a hectic gun battle or silent takedown.

Absolution marks a bold new direction for the Hitman series that focuses less on player freedom and more on telling a defined narrative. While the levels and poorly-implemented Instinct mode are sure to anger and frustrate fans of the series, Absolution still succeeds at providing an entertaining and most importantly, engaging gameplay experience that is difficult to put down until the credits roll. Both the expansive Contracts mode and stunning graphical overhaul help in overcoming the issues associated with the restrictive campaign levels.

Recommended

reviewText: Not what I expected from the Hitman franchise. I read all the reviews, saying how this game was a critical masterpiece, under-appreciated, etc. I didn't find this to be the case at all.\nThe game is gorgeous, and the controls are good. But the actual gameplay is extremely frustrating. The game gives you a ton of ways to deal with your targets; however, the save system and score system get in the way of this every time. If you actually want to enjoy the game, then you have to ignore the score system. While previous Hitman games encouraged experimentation, this game actively discourages it by giving you - maybe - one checkpoint in each level, at the most. If you want to experiment with different routes or outcomes, be prepared to replay half the level every time you make a mistake (or suffer a humongous negative score).\nWhile there were a couple great moments (the Chinatown level really stood out as good), I felt like the majority of the game was just time spent redoing the same sections in order to get the game's score of approval. Not fun, for the most part.

reviewText:
UPDATED 2016: I decided to give this game another chance and began playing it again, however I've been unable to progress at all due to the game or Square Enix servers wiping my campaign progression... TWICE. Therefore, Hitman: Absolution is broken and was ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• in 2012, and is still ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• in 2016.
Summary
Wow what happened to this??? Each Hitman game got better & better, but Absolution brings the series crashing down. They tried to breathe new life & add new gameplay features to refresh the franchise: instead it just doesn't work, feels broken, frustrating & hilariously bad.

Kiddie Steam reviewer verdict:
- wore disguise, disguise blown in 5 seconds, so killed every1.
- walked past guard, nearly got detected so tilted head low. ran out of power, cudnt tilt head anymore. disguise blown, so killed every1.
- ran 2 exit, disguise blown. cudnt open exit door cos game wudnt let me, so killed every1.
- Stopped playing game, played agen next day, saves got wiped by square enix server. 3/10 wud NOT play this ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• game agen.

Hitman: Abomination - Problems in the first 5 minutes
The trademark disguise mechanic has been drastically altered for the worse. Nick an engineer's uniform, & every single engineer in the country will be able to see through your disguise in mere seconds: it's like they all have an entire database in their heads of what each other looks like. Even if you're half way across a map, partially concealed by a dumpster & have your back to everyone whilst in the shadows, they can still see through your disguise! What the hell??? When you have a series that successfully utilise a unique mechanic that works throughout each game, then you change it so much that it becomes broken & frustrating that you end up just forgetting about it & shooting your way through levels, something has seriously gone wrong.
The absolute (see what I did there) worse offender of the disguise mechanic is that when you take the clothes of someone wearing a full face mask HE DOESN'T PUT THE FACE MASK ON!!! In all past games, Mr. 47 could hide his face, yet now all of a sudden he refuses to wear anything to conceal his face, like he suffers from an allergic reaction to face cloth. It's no wonder why everyone can spot you through your disguise, seeing as you're the only one wearing a hazmat suit without a gas mask on looking like a prick.

Best way to play past the flawed disguise mechanic is to sprint full speed everywhere, hugging walls, hiding behind objects & ninja rolling between cover. It's embarrassingly sad & hilarious that sprinting through the entire level hiding behind things & rolling all over the place like a hyperactive toddler grants less suspicion then walking around the place like a fully grown man would normally do. The NPCs even make remarks like ‚Äúact like a grown man!‚Äù when you start trying to hide. Who would have thought that the game is self-aware.

But this is Hitman: Absolution I‚Äôm playing, not Splinter Cell or Metal Gear Solid Absolution, so why the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• am I rolling all over the place instead of blending in??? Speaking of which, you STILL can get detected when you‚Äôre wearing a disguise in a crowd of around 50 people.

Arcade mechanics lead to hilariously bad results
New to the series is Instincts mode. Switch it on & time slows down, the background will turn monochrome whilst enemies, their walk path & important objects will glow. Instincts mode also allows you to blend in, such as scratching your head or tipping your hat low to obscure your face as you walk past people. But the problem is using this drains your instincts meter (mana?) so if it runs out, suddenly Mr. 47 loses the ability to simply lower his head again. Seriously???
There are a few select objects in the world that you can use to blend in: this not only recharges your instincts meter, people no longer suspects you of being an assassin. I think I'd be pretty suspicious of a guy constantly mopping a tiny area in front of his feet for a straight 5 minutes or a Policeman inspecting a doughnut like he's counting the individual atoms on it. Did I mention once this meter runs out, you suddenly lose the ability to tip your hat low or scratch your head? Maybe 47 has a stiff neck and the mana metre is actually his muscle fatigue.

Regardless, these features in the game are so strangely unhuman-like & illogical it's ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•in‚Äô hilarious.

Other flaws
Other minor flaws of the game is not being able to choose gear during the campaign, linear missions, ability to hide multiple huge guns and objects in your coat, enemies not noticing you strangling someone to death right next to them, silencers attach instantly to guns,

Scoring System
Because it‚Äôs cool and it‚Äôs Square Enix, you have a scoring system that rates you on how well (or how ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•) you are during each mission. Whilst it‚Äôs a nice idea to try to rack up the highest score as possible, it‚Äôs frustrating when bad game mechanics hamper this. As you can imagine, I‚Äôve had to shoot my way through most levels, so most of my level score is in the minus thousands region. Anyone want to try to beat my lowest scores, huh??

Light at the end of the rainbow
Well, Hitman: Absolution isn‚Äôt that bad. It‚Äôs just far from good. As a Hitman game, it fails miserably. As a cover based shooter with minor stealth mechanics, it‚Äôs decent enough.

Conclusion
I brought this for my friend‚Äôs birthday sadly, and to this day I still don‚Äôt know if he forgives me. Heck, I don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôve even forgiven myself.

How can I best summarise this game? It's like that kid at school who boasts about driving an expensive sports car, has the latest ¬£2000 super computer & has 5 different girlfriends. Then one day to his horror, his over-affectionate mum comes to pick him up from school, tells everyone that he stays at home all day playing on his cheap Macintosh & he is scared of girls. Then he goes all embarrassed & tries to stop his mum, only to trip over & his pants fall down in the process, everyone laughs & ridicules him, then they all go away & never look at him the same way again & he is left disgraced & shamed. Hitman: Absolution is that kid.

reviewText:
While it isn't a bad game in and of itself, the game is brought down by pretending to be an entry in the Hitman franchise.
If this were a game about an assassin from an agency doing awesome things, I wouldn't mind in the least.

The gunplay feels satisfying enough to be preferrable to actual stealth for a number of people, which is a nice change from Kane and Lynch, the developer's last game. On the flipside, stealth is mostly avoiding people using cover while using disguises to make people notice you just that little bit less. This would be fine, except the points system only actually rewards one playstyle, even though the levels simply, at times, don't feel designed with harder difficulties in mind. More on that later.
The graphics, while beautiful, do sometimes end up a bit distracting. Namely because bald heads don't shine like that. Seriously, that ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• stands out as much as the out of character actions in the story.
Most obviously there is a MASSIVE contrast in the game between levels. You'll end up with some wonderfully crafted arenas dedicated to creatively murdering a target or targets... Before or after having to get to the arena through linear levels with boring stealth that have almost no resemblance to what you'd picture the Hitman series having. In the end, you have a very schizophrenic sense of pace and gameplay as a result of mixing Hitman level designers with Kane and Lynch level designers. This is even further compounded by the fact that, while Jesper Kyd didn't compose the score for the game, they mixed previous game's tracks in with the new score, only serving to emphasize how at odds with itself the game is.
The challenges, while doing a wonderful job of forcing you to know the levels (good and bad) by heart, singlehandedly break the scoring system, and while I do encourage the scoring system since it's a rarity in games these days, it needs a very serious overhaul in this game due to a number of serious loopholes and glitches.

All in all, you're left with a very flawed gem, not unlike the Hitman franchise, but not of the same sort by and far, a very, very mixed bag no matter who you are to be sure.

reviewText:
To this day, it has been 10 years since the release of Hitman Blood money, the game defined the Hitman style of play and is regarded as one of the best stealth games of all time, to which I agree.
6 years later we now have Hitman Absolution developed by IO interactive and published by Square Enix, is it better than Blood money? or does it fall flat? Let's start with the plot.

Hitman Absolution kicks off right after the Hitman book: Hitman Damnation by author Raymond Benson, which took place after Blood money. Agent 47 (The main character of the Hitman Franchise) is told by the new head of the ICA: Benjamen Travis, to assasinate 47's former handler Diana Burnwood. When 47 shoots Diana, she tells 47 to save a girl by the name of Victoria as her last dying wish. I thought the plot was pretty well done

Let's get this out of the way first, the game is absolutely gorgeous with highly detailed locations, great lighting, sharp textures, great character models and animations. However, there is a bit too much bloom, especially 47's bald head.

The gameplay mostly consists of you having to get from one end of a level to the other while trying not to get spotted by enemies. Some missions have you killing a certain target within an area and these sections are by far the best parts of the game. You have a variety of ways to kill your target which goes from using electricity, blow up, grind, burn alive, blow up, stab, and yeah you get the idea. If you're not the sneaky type and want to shoot your way through the game's serveral chapers, that is also an option, the gunplay is perhaps one of the most tight I've played in a third person shooter. In each level there is a item you can find called evidence, which can be used to boost your score, and this takes me to the new feature for the Hitman franchise: the points system.

In almost every level, you will be scored on how you completed a level, such as losing points if you had to kill an NPC and didn't hide the body, killed the target in a creative way, lose points when spotted, etc. When you got enough points, you can learn assassin techniques which can be used to make 47 more efficient, such as reducing the time it takes to reload your gun, run faster, more health, and you get the picture. A returning feature is the much loved disguise system since the first Hitman game, although it works a bit different here.

If you find a disguise in a level, you can then wear it and move among the enemy, however it does not shield you fully from the enemy. If an enemy or civilian sees you while wearing their clothing, they will take longer to realize that you don't belong here and will investigate, however the other people in different clothing will not find you suspicious. This new system definitely works in my opinion, and if it was like blood money, the game would be almost impossible to fail.

A new mode to the series is contracts mode, you pick one of the many levels in the game, look around and then mark 3 targets, kill them how you want, and put it online to see who can do the same hit more efficiently. This mode is probably the closest you'll get to Blood Money gameplay and is definitely a mode that shouldn't be avoided. When you complete a contract in contracts mode you earn money which can be used to buy upgrades for your guns, buy disguises, and more guns.

The sound design of the game is top notch, the music is well done even without Jesper Kyd, and the voice acting is superb, especially David Bateson who voices 47 who does an exceptional job.

The A.I. in this game is also pretty good, they will actively search for you if you are hiding and know when to take cover during fire fights. Although there were still parts where they did act strange, such as ignoring dead bodies and shooting in the wrong direction.


In the end, Hitman Absolution is an excellent edition to the Hitman franchise and shouldn't be overlooked just because it's not that much like Blood money. I even think Absolution is just as good as Blood money.

Hitman Absolution is beautifully executed.

This game should be called Splinter Cell Absolution.

You spend most of your time sneaking behind cover, subduing enemies, and crawling in vents through linear, segmented levels. The very essence of what makes a Hitman game is lost here. The Instinct system favors improvisation over careful planning, all the more since the maps have been replaced by a useless radar. That and the new disguise system makes blending in incredibly frustrating, so you have to make sure nobody sees you instead of hiding in plain sight like in previous iterations.

Gameplay-wise, this is clearly a waste of potential. If you are a Hitman fan, avoid this game. If you're not, then you'll probably be better off playing Hitman Blood Money anyway.

reviewText: As someone who wasn't a huge fan of the older Hitman games Silent Assassin and Blood Money, I really like the improvements in gameplay that Absolution made. Surely, hardcore fans of the older titles may be disappointed with the somewhat more linear structure of this game, but I thought that the superb stealth, shooting, and movement mechanics were exactly what this series needed, and Hitman Absolution delivers big time in the fun factor department. Gorgeous environments that are incredibly lit, fantastic sound mixing, and moody ambience really make Hitman Absolution a title to remember. It's a generous game with a lengthy campaign and a separate Contracts mode if you want to dig deeper into what the community is doing within the game. Rounding things out is a surprisingly cool story with some very memorable characters, including a blood-curdling, redneck villan that you'll never forget. Hitman has always been a hard game to classify, as it has practically become a genre unto itself. But while this title may polarize fans of the older titles, there has never been a better Hitman game for the newcomer to jump into and discover the one-of-a-kind experience that the Hitman franchise offers.

reviewText:
From the vacuum sealed mission area, to the awkward new instincs system. This game does not live up to as a Blood Money sucessor.

The new 'instincs' meter is an interesting concept, but implemented in the worst of ways. Specifically the costumes/disguises side of it. Back in BM (Blood Money), disguises would give you certain access to specific areas, within reason. Taking the opera house as an example, dressed as a cop you could access some backstage areas. As one of the target's priviate secuirty guard, you gained even more access, etc. The disguises had a certain limited usefulness based on where you were going to use it.

Now, I have no idea if the designers were having issues about 'how' to implement diguises in Absolution, but this whole 'skill meter' that goes down whenever someone even looks your way in disguise is a bit silly. In the very first mission, following the tutorial. You have to kill some guy in a tiny market, packed with people.

One of the ways to deal with the situation is to steal a poisonous fish to use it's poison against the target. Thing is, the fish is on a counter within a cooking stall. Even if you have a chef outfit, you need to hold down your 'instinc' ability so that you don't get spotted by the other cooks. Even though I was holding it down, seems when you pick up the fish that still triggers 'suspicion'. And then I had the cook chase me down until she called security...

The feeling of stealth and being 'mixed' in with the crowd is just completely ruined. The tutorial section gives out this sad mechanic when you have to use disguises a few times, but each time you still need to hold down the 'instincs' ability to not get your cover blown. And the AI's range for getting suspicious is ludicrous. If at least they would have kept it for 'face to face' encounters. So you want to play as the most discreet and skilled assassin in the world. A living myth who is usually given the Agency's most dangerous missions.
Absolution neither lives up to the hardcore roots of its past nor makes up to be a fun ride for the present. As such, I cannot recommend this game. It simply isn't about a hitman. Agent 47 is not given the respect he deserves; he no longer functions as a perfect contract killer. Read on and decide for yourself whether Absolution is worth your time and money.

Part 1: Gameplay and the Experience
Absolution is the first ever Hitman game that is a console to PC port. It's an above average one. Graphics and textures are good and the new game engine runs very smooth on a solid PC. By smooth I mean the game has minimal glitches and the 3rd-person OTS camera handles smooth. Too smooth. Keyboard rebindings and a number of visual (but not many game) settings are also included. And a new Instinct Mode is also there for those who need a helping" hand.

Well then. Now to the bad. Keep in mind that these are all my opinions

In Absolution however

For a game that demands both precision in every action and intuitive decision-making as fundamentals to master

Even if Hitman Absolution did not live to the expectations of the fans/critics,it is still a good game.The main problem with it was the lack of open world.You are forced to approach the level from a certain angle.It still gives you options but you do not feel as free as in the other Hitman games.

Putting that aside,the game offers a great story and develops Agent 47's character further.The game really gives you the feeling of a Hitman game.I personally enjoyed this game a lot even if I was a little disappointed.

Many critics of Hitman: Absolution made the mistake to equate the whole series with Blood Money - maybe because this was the only game they have played.

People that know the whole series (including me) are aware of the fact that the very first game Codename 47 was also very mutch about action (think of the end) and even the second part had some hardcore areas that could only be solved by shooting your way through because of the aggressive AI. Contracts was a very dark game and rediscovered some aspects of the story...

Every Hitman game is unique in his own way, so where does this strange idea come from that every part has to be like Blood Money?? Yes, it was with no doubt a great game with a reliable disguise system and fantastic missions - but Absolution also has it's very own strengths: great sound and graphics, smooth and polished gameplay, cool cinematics and a lot of details in most levels. Some areas (like Hope and Chinatown) are bigger than others and this is completely fine. In my second playthrough, I discovered eastereggs, new rooms and new ways of eliminating the target. reviewText:
What a fun game!  I have not played any of the other titles in the Hitman series but really considering that now if they are anywhere near as good as this game.

Game has a really good story and lengthy single player campaign.  There were a lot of good cutscenes between missions and the voice acting was well done.  I have a sneaking admiration for Agent 47 after playing the game.

What I really like is the dynamic gameplay.  The player can approach any of the mission target(s) any way they wish.  You can be as direct or discreet in taking out the target(s) but also have to be mindful to plan a way out once the target(s) are eliminated.  The dynamic nature of the gameplay forces the player to adapt to the situations as they happen.  In fact there are many challenges that are tied to these different approaches that will affect the final mission score.  Clean and discreet methods are generally more rewarded with a higher mission score but there are many ways to simply succeed at mission completion and that choice is entirely up to the player.

The contracts mode extends the life of this game once the single player content has been exhausted.  The player can design contracts for other players to play and compete for highest ranking on the online leader boards.  Players can also enter into contract challenges to determine who can complete the contract in the fastest and most efficient way.  The player also gains in-game currency when completing these player-made contracts and can spend this on weapon upgrades to make future jobs easier.  This form of online content was a very smart addition and fits the theme of the game nicely.

I really do like the scoring system that the game uses for both the single player campaign on the contracts mode.  This system keeps enticing me to try the missions and contracts again in a different and more efficient way to achieve the highest score.  This along with the dynamic nature of the gameplay will keep this game fresh for me for quite some time.

reviewText:
When this game first came out I was very much excited, especially after finding out that David Bateson was once again returning to voice Agent 47. IO Interactive had pushed Bateson aside for a no-name and didn't even give him a reason why he was replaced. When I found out they had changed their minds at the last second I rushed to Steam and pre-purchased Hitman: Absolution.

Probably the biggest mistake I've ever made.

What we have here is the weakest Hitman game in the franchise that was watered-down for casuals. Everything that made Hitman great was thrown out the door with this abomination. Okay, there are a few missions I like (or tolerate) but the rest of this game I pretty much can't stand. Contracts mode was kinda cool for awhile, but quickly got repetitive. The story was pathetic and made absolutely no sense. The cutscene kills were jaw-droppingly restrictive. This is Hitman. This is the sequel that followed Blood Money--the game where you had nearly no limitations. But yet, in Absolution, we are restricted in what we can do. What was the reasoning behind this decision?

Blood Money was not perfect and I know had some flaws, but to follow up such an amazing game with this... is annoyingly difficult to comprehend. I mean it took them six years to make this? Where did the work go? Why would it take so long to make something this bad? And now IO Interactive is planning to release Hitman 6 really soon. They published a letter to fans explaining that the new Hitman game would have more of what everyone wanted and less of what was in Absolution. That's pretty much IO Interactive admitting that Absolution was crap.

Well, let's hope that Hitman 6 really will be much better. Absolution was a major disappointment and really not worth the time or money. Maybe I'll play it again when I'm bored, but every time I think about it I get Nam flashbacks.

reviewText:
I didn't expect to like this too much.  It received a degree of negativity on release, and I never really got to grips with Blood Money.  However, I LOVE stealth games and decided to give it a go thanks to sales.  Glad I did!  At this late stage I'm probably preaching to the converted, so this review is aimed at anyone else who couldn't really get into Blood Money either.

The goodThe primary reason this title gets attacked is that it's not open-world.  It's not, but the worlds presented to Agent 47 are still pretty large and there feels like 101 different ways to deal with targets.  It didn't feel overly linear like some titles.  There were many different approaches you can take to reach your targets, hiding and sneaking strategies offered, many weapons, distractions and disguises.  There are a whole variety of ways in which to complete your asignments without firing a shot or being anywhere near the victim.  The AI isn't exactly epic but does the job well enough (it's on a par with most other stealth games where the AI patrols their areas in a timed and predictable fashion).  Their narrative was the usual repetitive statements (very much like Dishonored though perhaps not as bad) and you soon begin to realise that guards aren't saying things because they've actually seen you, but because it is the next line to be spoken in the databank of lines.  Plenty of other games do this too, so that's no biggie.  What the game did well was making many varied people models so there was no feeling of copy-pasted NPCs everywhere.  Crowds were very convincing.  Animations of just about everything was fluid.  The locations were impressive, offering many different routes and places to hide without being overly obvious in their use of props for Agent 47 to use as cover.  Agent 47's use of multiple disguises was a great mechanic and a staple of the series.

Another reason I've seen this title attacked is because it is an 'action' game.  No, it's not, but it CAN be played as an action title if players prefer that and oftentimes it can be easier and all too tempting to play that way, but if you do, you rob yourself of the silent assassin experience that the game achieves so well.  I found it much better to 'role-play' as a deadly, silent and fatally efficient assassin who must not be detected at any cost, and the game offered a much better challenge as a result.  There is a huge range of (often rather similar) weaponry, most of which is arguably redundant if playing the game 'properly' (ie by stealth).  More useful were the number and variety of objects to be used as distractions.  Weapons, when used, were satisfying and the sniper rifle was a joy to use.  Unlike Blood Money, the controls are extremely simple and effective this time.  No more missing with the wire or fumbling around for exactly the right weapon.  Gamepads are fully supported with a properly-working auto-aim for people who want that advantage.  The opening chapter is a very effective tutorial chapter to introduce all the game mechanics you'll use.

The overall stealth aspect of the game is fabulous with a perfect difficulty pitch.  If you enjoy stealth play, this has to be in your library of games!  Although the game felt somewhat short, I was surprised to find it took me around 32 hours to complete the game end to end.  I definitely want to replay it!

Finally, the controls are pure joy!  Much improved over Blood Money's clunky, messy PC controls.  This is an easy game to play - perfect for people without Olympic Gold Medals for gamepad dexterity!


The badThe game commits the cardinal sin of several 'points of no return'.  Why don't developers understand how game-breaking it can be to have a door closing permanently behind you without warning, with no way to return?  It breaks the immersion, it prevents players from returning for collectibles (more on those soon) and yet they're really not necessary.  Sure, games often need to be semi-linear if we are to be given rich and varied worlds to play in, and a new map needs to be loaded and the old one flushed out of memory, but at least give us some gateway back to an earlier checkpoint within the same chapter even if that does mean a loading screen here and there (similar to the design of Dishonored where maps would funnel back to one doorway that triggered a reload of the previous area).  As much as people complain about loading screens, they are certainly preferable to denying the player any means of retracing steps if anything has been missed - especially in a game where the player cannot save their progress manually.

The other element I didn't like were many of the in-game achievements.  There were many that were excellent (often covering the many and varied ways of taking down a target) but then there were the collector hobbyist's busywork challenges!  Basically, these amounted to finding a massive inventory of objects in each chapter.  You can spend far too much time picking up and dropping bottles, bricks, ornaments, wrenches, hammers, the occasional mannequin arm or a dog bone(!) - you name it, you need to grab it for the 'find' to be registered - only to get to the end and find you missed a whole load more.  It reached the point where Agent 47 was leaving quite a trail of broken and dropped debris behind him (hardly stealthy) and it broke the whole role-playing vibe (I felt more like an antiques vs junk collector vs home-wrecker rather than deadly assassin)!  Why even bother doing it then?  The problem is that the game informs you that you only completed, say, 17 out of 40 achievements.  You might have achieved all the important ones (the assassination hits and such), but such a low number results from not being a kleptomaniac and leaves a less than satisfied feeling for the completionist type of gamer.

Finally, the story didn't really go anywhere.  It started out okay, but never really warmed up.  It was 'acceptable' in that it at least had a story unlike (polite cough) Thief 2014, but the whole thing really built up to - well, nothing!  I can't really say much without going into spoilers, but let's say that the final epilogue is a huge disappointment when compared to the earlier strong gameplay and was over all too easily - with the final expected 'boss fight' completely removed from the player's hands.

And the summary...Despite those horrid points of no return, Hitman Absolution is a strong contender in the stealth genre.  It's at its best when played as intended: as a secret and silent assassin.  You can go in all guns blazing but it won't be the same satisfying experience.  If you didn't enjoy Blood Money, don't write this one off - especially if you've enjoyed games like Dishonored or the Thief franchise.  Definitely recommended!

reviewText:
Hitman Absolution is a fantastic game. As a professional killer the game offers you a wide range of possibilities to eliminate your targets. Shoot, strangle, electrocute or poison them, break their necks, slit their throats or let them disappear in different kind of accidents. A great story separates the game in 18 very diversified levels. And while you have the freedom to kill everything that moves the basic idea of the game is to remain stealthy and complete your missions unnoticed like a ghost. This however demands patience. Take your time to investigate your environment before you make your move. Hitman Absolution is no game for nervous trigger fingers.

Every mission is rated. The more people you kill the less points you will collect. This is a great way to reward your play style. Beside the main target every level has challenges. Completing the challenges will grant you additional points. Depending on the selected level of difficulty your multiplier will rise or fall. Besides the personal satisfaction of gaining a high result you can compare it with your friends and other players.

The game also lets you create individual maps based on existing single player levels. These maps can then be played by other players. This however is rather disappointing but it's only a bonus that nobody really needs.

Pros:
- Strong atmosphere
- Nice story, very well scripted
- Very good voice acting
- Good sound and music
- Very good level design
- Good controls
- Realistic enemy behavior, very good AI
- Very entertaining
- Extremely detailed environments
- Nice humor (meet Kane and Lynch or find Lara Crofts ammo bag)
- Good (somewhat aged) in-game graphics
- Interesting locations
- High replayability
- Many ways to disguise (costumes)

Cons:
- Poor, blurry cut-scenes
- Sometimes long loading times
- Disappointing level editor, if you can even call it an editor

To get the most out of this game I recommend playing it on hard difficulty with the aim to remain unseen.

reviewText: As someone who wasn't a huge fan of the older Hitman games Silent Assassin and Blood Money, I really like the improvements in gameplay that Absolution made. Surely, hardcore fans of the older titles may be disappointed with the somewhat more linear structure of this game, but I thought that the superb stealth, shooting, and movement mechanics were exactly what this series needed, and Hitman Absolution delivers big time in the fun factor department. Gorgeous environments that are incredibly lit, fantastic sound mixing, and moody ambience really make Hitman Absolution a title to remember. It's a generous game with a lengthy campaign and a separate Contracts mode if you want to dig deeper into what the community is doing within the game. Rounding things out is a surprisingly cool story with some very memorable characters, including a blood-curdling, redneck villan that you'll never forget. Hitman has always been a hard game to classify, as it has practically become a genre unto itself. But while this title may polarize fans of the older titles, there has never been a better Hitman game for the newcomer to jump into and discover the one-of-a-kind experience that the Hitman franchise offers.\n9.8/10\n

Many critics of Hitman: Absolution made the mistake to equate the whole series with Blood Money - maybe because this was the only game they have played.

People that know the whole series (including me) are aware of the fact that the very first game Codename 47 was also very mutch about action (think of the end) and even the second part had some hardcore areas that could only be solved by shooting your way through because of the aggressive AI. Contracts was a very dark game and rediscovered some aspects of the story...

Every Hitman game is unique in his own way, so where does this strange idea come from that every part has to be like Blood Money?? Yes, it was with no doubt a great game with a reliable disguise system and fantastic missions - but Absolution also has it's very own strengths: great sound and graphics, smooth and polished gameplay, cool cinematics and a lot of details in most levels. Some areas (like Hope and Chinatown) are bigger than others and this is completely fine. In my second playthrough, I discovered eastereggs, new rooms and new ways of eliminating the target. Yes, story and points system are strange and not every level offers a lot of stealth varieties but the game just didn't deserve all the extreme and frivolous reviews of some fans".

Absolution is fine the way it is - because it's an individual part of the series that still upholds most of the traditions of Hitman. I rather like to play some new aspects than the same style and content again and again.

reviewText:
Each level can be completed in multiple ways, though it requires such precision and care, you can forget doing it on your first attempt. Or second. Or third, for that matter. It's like one of those old arcade games, where the slightest mistake, your fault or not, will cause it to become a bloodbath.

The beauty of the older games was that it was a sandbox. You could complete the level in the way you wanted. You could put on a disguise and become a GOD. Disguises now serve next to no purpose since anybody with a similar outfit will be able to recognise you.

The graphics are nice and some of the levels have that same old Hitman magic (the ones where people don't just shoot you on sight). However, the game is far too frustrating to play properly. If you want to reach the end of the game, expect to give up and shoot everybody in some of the missions, or to be at this game for months replaying every level hundreds of times before you learn and perfect the exact route that works.

If anybody doesn't know what to expect from a Hitman game, you have to kill certain people and you get a better score if you do it secretly or make it look like an accident. The levels are large and semi-open-ended, with lots of NPCs and pointless but fun details. If you want to know what all the fuss is about, try Blood Money, which is a really good game and has aged wonderfully. This game, on the other hand, was dated in its style before it was even released. Oh and there's no such thing as the colour black in this game, since it's always smeared with a filter. Sometimes it makes it look very cinematic, other times it's downright annoying. But that could be ignored if the gameplay itself wasn't so perfectly flawed.

reviewText: I've played and enjoyed all the Hitman games (except I did not enjoy the very first one, I find it unplayable), so I was looking forward to this. It definitely takes the gameplay a bit into the Deus Ex: HR / Alpha Protocol realm, which I really don't mind since I love those games. The melee is all QTE stuff, but the overall game controls are a huge improvement over Hitman: Blood Money and the earlier games. In Blood Money, for example, pushing the interact button on someone had a completely unpredictable effect; you may punch them, or push them, or maybe knock them out, or maybe just annoy them and alert everyone to your presence. It was really annoying. This game does it infinitely better. The disguise system and blend-into-the-crows system are great, too. The save (checkpoint in Absolution) system is much less versatile, though, which is too bad, but not really too much of a hindrance since levels are generally very small and confined compared to earlier games. Overall, I really like it so far and think it improves upon the series in a lot of ways.\n\nI can see why many Hitman fans didn't like the campaign. Each mission is a series of smallish levels, and only one or two of the mini-levels might have assassination targets. The levels with no assassination targets are more like your standard stealth-action game fare than traditional Hitman style missions. Mostly, it's just sneaking past guys to get to the next area. The actual assassination levels are great, and I like the way challenges give you both goals to play for and hints on various ways to kill a target. Contracts mode is is pretty neat, and can fulfill the desire of series fans for a murder playground" just fine

reviewText:
Intro
In Hitman: Absolution you play as Agent 47 who tries to finish a personal contract in which forces him to lie to his Agency which makes him battle between two sides. You visit lots of diffrent locations and take care of people.

Good Points
The Storyline is great and keeps you intrest all the way though with a few plot twists and the characters are really intresting thoughout the story.

Controls are easy and you will pick them up quickly as there easy to learn. Sometimes you loose control when the camera moves on its own, but its not to bad.

The levels are all unique with every level being in a diffrent place and situation. This keeps you intrested and keeps you playing.

Grathics in Absolution are nice and look great because there is alot of detail in the game. The lighting is the best feature in the grathics because its very realisic fits the tone of the game.

The slow motion feature great as it can help you kill or give you more time to think on what to do. It also gives you some clues which can be helpful.

Music in Absolution is good, not amazing but it fits the scene and helps you understand the situation. It just works which is what you need.

The length is good, its around 10 to 12 hours long if your rushing though but you can but over 20 hours if you playing the game slow. There is so many things you can do and each level is replayeble so you can get your moneys worth if you wanted to.

Bad Points
Towards the end you start to realise that each level has the same layout in what your supposed to do. Its always find this room then find your target. Works well but you notice it towards the end.

The Multiplayer Contracts become boring very quickly which makes you not even want to try again. I'd just play single player since you get a better experience.

It diffrent from over hitman games and a few fans say they like Blood Money more since its alot better. So you you've played every over hitman game then dont be taken back when you play Absolution since its diffrent.

Overall
In my opinion I think that Hitman: Absolution is a great game and I would recommend it to anyone who likes stealth games. If you a big fan of the Hitman series then you might not like it as much but for someone new then you should start with this game. I rate Absolution 7 out of 10.

reviewText:
First, let me start off by saying that i was following this franchise right from 2004, this is THE one of the first games i ever played, a great start of a gaming career if you ask me. That being said, let me first tell you how this game makes me feel as a Gamer - Thrill and Power. Yes, having absolute control over life and death with a well crafted character with a wide range of skills, who can easily take down every single enemy on the level, or pass through like a ghost. This game, or rather this Franchise, sets a good mark of an assassin - and that is planning and strategizing. There is always ANOTHER way of killing an enemy, always a different aproach, and while you get rewarded for more creative ways, don't let the score discourage your playstyle. That is the beauty, and that is what it makes me feel as a gamer. Now off to a more technical aproach.
Optimisation is an absolute win, i benchmarked this game with ultra settings on my lenovo y50, which has an integrated and nvidia gtx850m and you can easily pull over 30 fps. Tearing is kind of annoying with disabled vsync, it does eat quite the amount of memory, but it's really not a big problem, as mentioned, optimisation is amazing and you can pull this game even on older PCs. Graphics, visual effects, lightning, and blood are spectacular, honestly, i haven't found any bad graphical glitches or bugs.
Audio/Soundtrack is dynamic and again, gives you the feeling of control, almost acts as a vital guide on harder difficulties. Gives you the sense of a situation, and allows you to steadily go with the flow. Audio is really important for me in the game, and i found it really suitable for this type of gameplay. I absolutely loved it.
Last, but not least, is gameplay. I believe you kinda get the sense of the gameplay from what was mentioned above, but let me mention a couple of new features that i found interesting:
Instinct. Bloody hell, i love this feature. Not because it can make a game easy, but because it gives you a choice on how do you want to play this. I love how developers removed every most important aspect of instinct" on higher difficulties

reviewText:
It's going to be very difficult to divide this review in pros and cons. I would have liked a 'mixed' button for the recommandation rating, because I don't know what to think of this game.

O.K.

+/ Nice level design.
+/ Interesting and new locations with refreshing levels.
+/ The assasinations levels are cool.
+/ Smoother, easier to read gameplay than in previous iterations.
+/ There is a story, and it is not that bad!
+/ Good voice acting.
+/ The Contracts mode is FUN.
+/ Cool weapons feeling.


-/ Dumbed down version of traditional Hitman games.
-/ The gameplay is not varied enough to be truly fun.
-/ Between two assasinations, there are a few linear  levels that feel like Splinter Cell with less moves, less options and a very flat design.
-/ Instinct mode is frustrating and forced into gameplay.
-/ The A.I sucks.
-/ Scoring system is annoying. No, let me rephrase that. It's ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•T.

/Absolution is plain weird. I played all Hitman games before, and I don't understand it. It's not that bad. It's just not that good either. Everything contradicts itself into this game. You have a lot of options, but if you want to be efficient and sneaky, the game can feel really dull.

As I said before, this feels like the best way to play is to play a weird version of Splinter Cell with an assassination gimmick. You can still disguise in a variety of costumes, but it is broken by the instinct system. Enemies are suspicious of anyone having the same costume as theirs, and you need to replenish a jauge of 'instinct' that you will need to cross the way of any guard with the same costume without attracting uneeded attention.

So how does that translate?

Let's say you enter a zone with a lot of guards patrolling (The 'Run for your life' level comes to mind.) and that you succeded in attracting a guard, stunning him and stealing his clothes. There are a lot of his pals patrolling the area, and, with your costume on, you decide to casally walk to the exit. But unfortunately for you, if you encounter one of your colleagues, he will become suspicious, forcing you to press Lctrl to avoid them by hiding your face, thus depleting instinct.

And once it's empty, your costume is useless. Meaning that most costumes in Absolution are actually useless, because there a not enough variety in the NPCs you encounter to change costumes a lot, and that even if you could, taking down non target NPCs costs you points.

What's the point then? The basic controls for 47 are fluid, with the addition of a cover system which I feel is not a bad idea at all. But they are not as developped as the controls of, say, Sam Fisher in the Splinter Cell story, which makes basic infiltration very flat. Yes, it's sandbox, yes you can just play as you wish, but with a scoring system as invasive as Absolution's (seriously, the score indicator takes like a tenth of the screen.) you always feel punished when you experiment stuff.

The assassinations are the high point of the game, but it's so weird that not every level consists of simply kill a target in an inventive way! I can understand it goes with the story of the game (47 is betrayed by its agency, this time it's personal, blah blah blah, girl to save, blah, blah, blah.), but this game is so empty of real  cool moments!

If you don't compare the contracts of previous Hitman games with the ones in Absolution, those are really nice. There are a lot of options, a lot of paths to said options, and the level design of those areas is really well done. It always feel fun to kill someone in a stupid accident, poisoning him, pushing him to his death, sniping him or just garroting him. But then again, a mission like the King of Chinatown, while being a nice throwback to the very first Hitman missions (Aaaah, the Hong Kong levels.), feels empty when compared to levels of Hitman: Blood Money.

And maybe that's the problem with Absolution. Maybe I would be less unforgiving if it was not the black sheep of a glorious series of game which encouraged cautiousness, intelligence, and creativity. Absolution has a lot of arguably good points, but its gameplay sucks for old timers like me. There are a few additions I like, such as the Contracts mode which allows you to play missions with rules invented by other players, like killing a guard in a room full of his pals with a Samurai armor and your bare hands.

It is simply not enough. I can't recommand this game, and can only advise that you get Hitman Blood Money if you're searching for the ultimate sandbox assassin experience. Then again, maybe you're just searching for a light stealth/action game. I don't know. This game confuses me./

reviewText:
Story: Now in this game we continue's on from Blood money. The game begins with Agent 47 detailing his relationship with his handler Diana Burnwood whom he had trusted until she, without explanation, betrayed the International Contract Agency (ICA) by sabotaging their funding and database, using the subsequent confusion to vanish. After the ICA is reformed, 47 is tasked by his new handler, Benjamin Travis, a high level official within the ICA, to kill Diana for her betrayal and retrieve an important Agency asset named Victoria from her mansion in Chicago, Illinois. 47 sneaks into her mansion and shoots Diana. Rather than finishing her off, 47 comforts the dying Diana and asks her why she betrayed the ICA. Diana reveals everyone has their limits over the bad things they have done and she discovered hers after learning about Victoria, a teenage girl who is genetically-engineered to be an Assassin within the ICA. Not wishing to see Victoria suffer the same fate as 47, she betrayed the ICA and escape with her. As her final request, Diana ask 47 to protect Victoria, and he agrees to do so. Because 47 refuses to return Victoria to him, Travis brands 47 a traitor.

Now this story revolves around Victoria, ICA and more other great story characters. It is certainly a very good story well done to. I enjoyed it.

Game Play: The game play takes place in America e.g. The United States. Which is different that around the world like the old Hitman games. But I will try not to compare it to the old ones. Now we have the addition of the online feature called Contracts which you can compete against other players around the world doing contracts and even make your own to challenge your friends and others. Also the addition of this instinct feature. Which you can see through the walls and the enemies followed by using it to distract the enemies. Shame there is no in story weapon customization of the weapons and the load out choice to.

Controls: Controls are simple to learn as always even for the new player which is good.

The Graphics: Just amazing. Such an improvement. You can see it in the game and the cinematic's to. The detail on the weapons to and on Mr 47 even the npc's. I can not see a fault in it.

Music: It worked well with the game, it set the scenes up great even in the cinematic's to. I did not even want to turn it off which I did with the old games.

Bugs and Glitches: Well as with any new game these years there is always bugs and glitches. But there was only one or two. First would be crashing in loading sections and the other where the save file is unable to sync up. Other than that I could not come across any other. Many people have said of corrupt save files. I wounder if its connected to the failing to sync up.

Reply Value: There is certainly replay value in this game. Going through each difficulty level and there is the contracts side.

Overall: Great story as always, Game play just gets better with additions of a new skill and environments in America. Bar the loss of the weapon load out set and story mode customization's of the weapons. Controls simple to learn and use. Graphics just amazing. Music in the game adds to the game suspense. As I said there is always bugs and glitches hopefully these will be sorted. So for this next great installment to the Hitman Series. I give this game 9 paws out of 10

reviewText:
This game is a very worthy addition to the Hitman series. I have to admit, I wasn‚Äôt particularly a Hitman fan. Blame my best friend. One day he lent me Codename 47, Silent Assassin and Contracts all in order to play in retail boxes. Back then I was merciless to any frustration and played every single game on the hardest difficulty. These days I play games on Normal. And this is one of those games where I‚Äôd recommend playing it on Normal for the first time.

Hitman is all about achieving ‚ÄúLinear Gameplay Perfection‚Äù. And that‚Äôs a lot harder than you may think. You have to know your environment. You need to know the timing of the characters paths. You need to know the various ways you can eliminate a single target discreetly.

This brings me to say what you can do, but don‚Äôt want to do. You can go on a massacre run. I tried this out in a courtroom map for the fun of it. But eerily it was horrifyingly realistic. You can hear people begging for their lives and stuff. And all I could think about was, ‚ÄúMy gawd, this is like some American high school shootout simulator.‚Äù Unlike the previous Hitman games where it felt like you were a badass against bad guys and nobody could mess with you. Hitman: Absolution penalizes you with a scoring system. In effect this game literally forces you to play the right way unlike its predecessors.

Ignoring the challenges, there is an XP system in place that unlocks skills as you progress. None of the older Hitman games did this. In fact I‚Äôm starting to feel like a lot of today‚Äôs game development companies are just chucking similar systems in for the heck of getting a player to play the game more. I‚Äôm not against this idea (because it hasn‚Äôt bothered me yet). But I also don‚Äôt endorse this idea. I‚Äôd rather have game developers focus on the real reasons why people return back to playing a game. Things like fun factor ‚Ä¶ etc. Not some progress bar that tells you how much you‚Äôve done.

Hitman: Absolution is powered by the Glacier 2 game engine. This is a game engine that I would commend. It seems very sophisticated. A lot of the mechanics from the older Hitman games have been enhanced. Everything seems more precise and graphically illustrated, as opposed to just having a hunch.

Hitman games have a certain aesthetic that evokes a particular mood that is truly unique. Whilst Hitman: Contracts has my favorite introduction movie, Hitman: Absolution has by far one of the most classy, simplistic and quick switching main menu interfaces you will ever witness.

I want to talk about the crowd which literally looks like hundreds of people on a single map. When I first spotted this in ‚ÄúHitman: Blood Money‚Äù back in 2007, I was like, ‚ÄúThis is just ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ic. How the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• did they do this?‚Äù Forward to 2013, the technology is still unbelievable. You can still bump into each individual or kill them one by one if that is your thing. Whilst this was the same for ‚ÄúKane & Lynch 2: Dog Days‚Äù, they made an improvement for Hitman: Absolution. reviewText: Hitman Absolution is a solid stealth game that knows the true meaning of the genre. You move through non-linear levels taking out targets however you want, and there are bonuses for completing the level multiple times, killing your foes however you want.  Want to run in guns blazing and kill everyone? You can do that. Want to make your kill look like an accident? You can do that too. Each level has various ways to approach each and every kill, and they are all vastly different. Some require high skill, some do not. The game looks great with the Glacier 2 engine, the story is quite easy to understand even if you have never played a Hitman game before, but is still detailed enough to add a few twists and turns, and the amount of weapons you have throughout the game is vast. Completionists will be at home with this game; it has tons of replay value and the Contracts mode adds to that. The game has a couple of flaws though. Why is everyone suspicious of you when you wear the same disguise as them? They surely would not know every single person in the area who had that occupation. The game can be annoying at times, especially the final part of the final level where the enemies spot you in an instant. Overall, 8/10.
