reviewText:
It has been a long time since we‚Äôve seen Agent 47 in action, but while he was sitting back and sipping on margaritas in the tropics, the world of gaming has changed significantly. Third person shooters and even ‚Äústealth‚Äù games now offer a stronger emphasis on speed and multiplayer combat. IO Interactive may have had a tough time this generation experimenting with new intellectual properties, but surely they know what they‚Äôre doing with their biggest franchise. Can the ultimate assassin bounce back into the game, or has he fallen from grace?
Mechanically speaking, this is very much a Hitman game with a number tweaks to the overall mission structure. You‚Äôll still be strangling guys with fiber wire, locking in chokes and pulling out 47‚Äôs trademark Silverballers when things get hairy, but it‚Äôs all presented in a more fashionable manner. The camera plays a slight role in this as the closer over the shoulder perspective works well with the more personal tale, along with takedowns and slow motion kills adding to the overall cinematic nature.
Unlike past games, though, this isn‚Äôt just the agency pumping out mission after mission. With Agent 47 going rogue, he has his own agenda to attend to, and at the moment it‚Äôs all about rescuing and protecting a mysterious young girl. Because of this, Agent 47 won‚Äôt be dropped into random locations around the world; he‚Äôll stick to the United States of America and follow a linear storyline with minor branching options that can change dialogue in set areas. Don‚Äôt be fooled, though; while the story is told in a linear manner, each location is its own sandbox in which players can sift through. There are a wide variety of paths to take and an abundance of clothing to steal in the incredibly meaty world. It‚Äôs all about carefully stalking a target and finding the best time to strike without being seen, creating a sense of tension that‚Äôs both entertaining and nerve-racking.
There are twenty missions in all and they can range from literally less than a minute to hours long depending what kind of play style is used. Taking the stealth route, which is how it was meant to be played in the first place, offers a variety of ways to approach a situation, creating a good sense of replayability. Pulling out the Silverballers and go gung-ho is certainly an option, but that‚Äôll obviously attract unnecessary attention and put guards on alert. There‚Äôs no one way to kill someone as IO Interactive have given players an array of creative ways to dispose of their targets and a number of alternate areas that most will likely miss on their first playthrough.
A new feature that is more than welcome to the Hitman formula is instinct. People in this world seem incredibly suspicious as no longer will walking past someone of the same trait, such as a criminal or police officer, allow safe passage. It‚Äôs an exceptional new stealth mechanic that allows Agent 47 to blend into the world around him a little more reasonably, but there are some issues with it. It makes sense that disguising yourself within a small group of people wouldn‚Äôt be realistic, but when fifty police officers are on scene, blending in as a cop shouldn‚Äôt be an issue. Enemies will also start to become suspicious even if your back is turned to them and they‚Äôre thirty feet away.
Similar to past games, Hitman grades how well a mission is accomplished and hands out rewards accordingly. Instead of receiving cash to upgrade weapons, which is instead done through the online Contracts mode, Agent 47 is given a numeric score which, if high enough, will give him upgraded abilities such as moving faster and blending into crowds better.
The Hitman franchise is all about trial and error and becoming the best assassin possible. Past games have had the ability to save anywhere during a mission and revert back to it whenever needed, allowing multiple approaches to different scenarios without having to go too far back. Unfortunately, Hitman: Absolution strips away the feature adds a number of checkpoints that are both automatically and manually obtained.They are generally well placed, but the biggest issue is that instead of saving everything that‚Äôs happened, it just resets the entire world from that spot.
While the game has changed how the franchise will move forward, the online mode titled Contracts will bring fans back to the classic style of play. Instead of going with the flow of the main storyline, players will be able to set hits on whoever they please during a mission, allowing others around the world to try and best them and rack up cash for upgrades in the process. It‚Äôs an ambitious online multiplayer mode that gives gamers the freedom to play a traditional Hitman experience, simply going from kill to kill.
It‚Äôs also notable that Hitman: Absolution looks absolutely gorgeous. Having a powerful, but not top of the line rig, I was able to max everything out and still stay between thirty and sixty frames-per-second at all time. The number of bodies that IO Interactive is able to put on screen is overwhelming, making the crowd blending mechanics believable.
While still very much a traditional stealth game, Hitman: Absolution has changed the series for the best in offering cinematic quality combat. It has a stronger focus on telling a coherent story while keeping a slow methodical pace. With a terrific single player campaign and a compelling online multiplayer component, it‚Äôs safe to say that whether or not you were a fan of the series before, you will be now. Even with its imperfections, Hitman: Absolution is a magnificent achievement that goes well beyond expectations and will lead future stealth action titles into a better tomorrow.

reviewText:
Hitman: Absolution's biggest problem is that everything that was gained in Blood Money is simply forgotten about. The instinct system, while clever, creates a mechanic where the entire game is about being literally hidden, instead of the awesome social stealth that Blood Money used instead. The better graphics are in exchange for corridor, box'ish levels, where the goal is to simply get from area to the next.

There is no consequences about open firefights, bar say that Agent 47 will be gunned down by a cluster‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• of enemy guards 90% of the time due to the clunky cover system (or be killed in the most frustrating QTE sequences ever). The disguise system being enhanced by Instinct breaks the entire game on the harder difficulty levels. Since the guards' presence is increased heavily on the Professional difficulties, you WILL be caught and a firefight WILL break out.

Lets say I'm disguised as a vendor clerk for a Chinese food stand. Does every single fast food vendor in a 10 mile radius know my identity and run to the police to say im a dangerously armed assassin?

...They do here.

reviewText:
Contracts was my introduction to the Hitman series, and the creative license we were given to complete the job was the gift that kept on giving. Depending on the weather, one could opt to be professional and keep things quiet or go on a Sterling Archer-esque rampage.

Absolution, however, decides to take that agency away and puts you in the uncomfortably tighter suit of a restrictive narrative, much like your mother did when you were flower boy at your Uncle Gerald's wedding. Unfortunately, the aforementioned narrative is done in disappointingly poor taste, and Absolution's linear nature does not lend itself well to multiple replays.

Filled with ghoulish, hideous caricatures which are supposed to pass some semblance of human beings, Absolution catapults you into the grungy abyss of a metaphorical (and at one point literal) sex dungeon.

It remains a competent stealth-action game and there's certainly some fun to be had if you're truly, desperately bored...but try as you might, you can't wash the smell of grindhouse out long after you've left.

reviewText:
I've been a long-time fan of this series since the first installment by Eidos, Hitman: Codename 47. It's gotten a lot better with each subsequent installment, and this is no exception.

This game defines what it means to use stealth. Much like Splinter Cell, or Thief, this game rewards you for your patience, and puts it to the test with each stage. The game isn't particularly long either, with each mission area being fairly short, with minimal objectives to complete, but it's the time it takes to wait for that guard to finish his route, or the two civilians holding a conversation to move along that makes the game long and enjoyable.

The game's basic plot is you're given a mission to eliminate an Agency rat and through the act of actually getting to your target, you learn there's something bigger at play, and you defy your commanding officer, setting a string of events in motion that will put your will to the test.
You're thrown into the game with a minimalistic prologue/tutorial that tells you the basics of sneaking around and causing distractions, killing, subduing, hiding bodies, etc... and then before the mission is over, you're introduced to the rating system. A system that awards points for positive actions (objectives, hiding bodies, evidence, silent kills, etc...) and penalizes you for naughty actions (getting spotted, killing/pacifying non targets, killing civilians, etc...). The goal is to maximize your score on each mission by completing challenges and completing your objectives in a multitude of (creative) ways. The best rating you can get on a mission is Silent Assassin, whereby you complete all your objectives only killing your intended target(s), and not getting spotted. This is the most difficult to pull off, but it makes it all that much more fun. The multiple challenges that you can complete are also presented in such a way that it requires multiple passes through a mission before you can claim them all (many are mutually exclusive), so the incentive is to keep thinking of new ways to win. The one downside to this system though, is that when you complete a challenge, it stays for good, so reloading a checkpoint is enough to give you the credit to complete the other challenges without a full playthrough.

The missions are tough and well scripted. The dialog and the musical score is top notch, though there are some lines that are pretty corny. The character cast is great and it can be sometimes hard to follow who's who, but they are all likeable (or dispicable). The game offers a wide spectrum of difficulty, whereby the harder you go, the tougher (and more plentiful) the enemies get, the more aware they are, and you get to use less of your instinct"

reviewText: As someone who's been playing Hitman since the very beginning, all I can do is mourn as one of my most favorite series nosedives with the release of Hitman Absolution. Had they created a new IP with an interesting world and story, this game might have been great. It's not a bad game in it of itself, but it is a bad Hitman game. The enviornments are small and limiting. You aren't even able to assissinate many of your targets--instead the game launches a cutscene where 47 either screws up the hit (WHAT!!?) or you get a cutscene where 47 barely is able to take out the target. Very dissapointing. Even worse are the levels. There's no trips to castles in Japan or various other interesting locales; no, we're stuck running around boring ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• middle America. Ugh, just remebering the game gets me going. At least it looks really pretty, if you can ignore the ridiculous amounts of bloom that is. Anyway, do yourself a favor and get Blood Money instead. Hell, I'd even recommend Silent Assssin over this.

reviewText:
Hitman‚Ä¶. The game where the only problem with the game is my skill.
Hitman Absolution in my opinion an amazing game, graphic wise and gameplay wise.

‚Äì Storyline 8/10
As much a fan as I am of the game, the storymode could have been worked on just a little more! I found it confusing to what‚Äôs happening from time to time. Sometimes I didn‚Äôt even know if there was a story mode. The story mode starts with you assassinated Diana. Your assignment is to kill Diana and bring Victoria a teenage girl who you find out later is quite special. The game becomes more interesting when you decide to hide Victoria in a nearby church therefore disobeying the Agency‚Äôs order.

‚Äì Controls 7/10
Controls of the game weren‚Äôt too bad, but were a bit wonky at times. I didn‚Äôt particularly like the idea of QTE‚Äôs for every close combat battle you get into though.

‚Äì A.I. 8/10
The A.I. was just spot on, untill they started hiding behind walls and shooting through them. I also had problems with the fact that everyone knows EVERYONE, I was no more special then the next guy, but apparently I stand out in a crowd. Also sometimes the A.I. somehow know where you are when trying to throw an item to distract them.

‚Äì Graphics 10/10
I honestly can‚Äôt complain about the graphics, I didn‚Äôt find any bugs or glitches in the particles around me. I also didn‚Äôt notice texture poping or not rendering. There are plenty of options for the resolution of the game for those who own a less powerful computer.

‚Äì Options 10/10
The options menu in a lot of games is quite poorly done, but in Hitman Absolution it was executed perfectly. You can change every control, the difficulty of the game, graphics and more.

‚Äì Gameplay 10/10
Obviously the main part of the game, executed perfectly. Hitman Absolution has 2 gamemodes to choose from ‚Äì Storymode & Contracts. The story mode explains itself. The contracts can add a few more hours after finishing story mode. In the Contracts mode you compete against friends and online players to who can be the best assassin. Little side note- If you fail any level in storymode or contracts it has a really quick and easy replayabilty. The Chaoters are split into multiple levels, which alows the levels to be designed better and makes it easier to replay if necessary. One of my most beloved aspects of the game is ‚Äì you can finish a level or choose a path in more than 1 ways. Often you will be given the choice to garote a victim or smash his head in with a vase you just picked up a minute ago.

‚Äì Final Verdict 8/10
The game in my opinion is amazing. I have nothing to add. Buy it. Play it. Enjoy it.

My personal GOTY Third-Person Shooter of 2012, sharing the slot with Max Payne 3.
Also my go-to recommendation for the Hitman Franchise and my personal favorite second to Blood Money.

This is the most intense and visceral of the franchise and has the most hardcore gameplay in my opinion.

They left out the ability to fully customize your loadout from Blood Money, but if you consider the context of the storyline you will understand why that is - You are excommunicated from the Agency and are on a mission for revenge.

You use the guns you find as well as the disguises you can locate/ steal off of the enemy.
The AI system has been completely overhauled, bringing the most superior and attentive AI yet.
Surveying your area is crucial if you want to survive.
Deciding who to kill and who to subdue has never been so important.
Fully interactive environment brings fresh mechanics - Hide in closets, trash bins, on window ledges.
Use what's around you to dispose of your enemy and cover your tracks.

11/10

reviewText:

Overall: A great Hitman game, but awful for beginners (especially because you get docked for knocking people out).

reviewText:
In many ways Absolution is as effective a franchise reboot as we‚Äôve ever seen, retaining almost everything that was good about the originals and while making the game more accessible for new players. It also has most of the same problems, or at least swaps them out for new ones, but maybe that at least will convince sceptics that IO hasn‚Äôt sold out.

In Short: A franchise reboot that retains most of what was great about the originals, and most of what was bad too ‚Äì but the sum total is still on target.

Pros: Excellent stealth mechanics, some great sandbox stages, and impressively inventive deaths. Great graphics and Contracts mode is an interesting curio.

Cons: Occasionally linear level design and too many non-assassination missions. Flawed save/checkpoint system. Horrible story, in more ways than one.

Score: 8/10

reviewText:
Hitman: Absolution ReviewFifth instalment of the Hitman franchise, very underrated stealth game.

This game is better than people give it credit for. Why do so many people dislike this Hitman instalment? I know it isn't Blood Money or Contracts but how could anyone say that this game isn't fun? It's really fun and to me, it's a must have in your Steam library. This is one of the most underrated games I've seen in a very long time. It seems to me that whatever Square Enix release is just pure gold, I've never ever played an awful Square Enix game and I'm hoping that I never will.

For everyone that keeps on going on about Blood Money, please, stop. I know it was a great game, and I know that this is nothing compared to it. But that does not make this game terrible.

The game is nice and short. Why is it nice? I don't particularly know, I just like short games sometimes rather than games that just drag on and on. Whilst I'd like a bit more replay value, other than that, the game is fantastic! Stealth mechanics are great, especially the point shooting. Activating distractions like radios and such is awesome. I especially love attacking people's necks from behind with a wire and subdueing them. If you love stealth and assassination, then definitely buy this game.

reviewText:
An excellent stealth game from an established series, Absolution made me enjoy the arts of assassination immensely. The tone of the game is slightly different this time, with 47 being on the run from his agency, though the plot isn't particularly interesting or engaging. What it does do is serve as a device to push Agent 47 to some great locations to ply his craft and sneaking through a level to eliminate a target is both familiar and wonderfully realised.

The objectives through each level are hardly revolutionary; get to target, kill target, escape. The pleasure is in the execution, with several different methods of accomplishing each objective. From a mysterious accident, to a poisoned drink, the signature garrotte and more, 47 has a vast array of lethal options at his disposal. You could even go in all guns blazing of you want, though I wouldn't recommend it; the shooting mechanics leave much to be desired; stealth is the focus here.

There are various methods of infiltration, many of which depend on the level. The most obvious options are either via the traditional stealth method, or by using disguises. Unfortunately both of these mechanics leave much to be desired. The stealth option has far too few actions available and consists of being able to crouch behind cover, move on ledges and hide bodies. Similarly, the disguise system is virtually useless as people wearing the same uniform can see through it, rendering the whole thing pointless in most settings.

The layout makes up for things a little and I ended up ignoring the disguises for the most part, preferring to sneak through the excellently set out areas. The level designs are fantastic, from bustling stations to the arid south.  Is South Dakota really like that? I thought it was quite lush. Also, I know it‚Äôs not southern ‚Äì it‚Äôs more the stereotype really.  I was genuinely impressed with just how atmospheric the various setting were, even if the strip-club that now seems mandatory in ‚Äúmature‚Äù games felt gratuitous and contrived. I also loved the dry humour present throughout the game. It‚Äôs subtle, only really there if you look for it, but I found it hilarious.

The new engine really shines in-game and it looks truly impressive at every step. Areas look simply stunning with excellent lighting, textures and attention to detail. The Chinatown level is particularly impressive, with a staggering amount of NPCs present, each moving independently, that really gives a feeling of stalking your prey through a busy city.


I‚Äôve noticed that truly great stealth games are incredibly rare these days, and I can‚Äôt remember the last game that actually demanded patience, thought and exploration. Absolution most certainly has the latter under its belt and whilst it wouldn‚Äôt be unfair to say that my recommendation is partly based on the lack of competition, it‚Äôs still highly enjoyable and I‚Äôd definitely recommend it.

Final Score:

7/10

It‚Äôs not going to be a classic, but it‚Äôs good enough for stealth fans.

I enjoyed hitman blood money very much, then i came to absolution and it is different for sure, but it's not a bad game at all...
yeah yeah, maybe the save system that's a bit weak, but just look past it..

The level design is pretty nice but most of the time it's just pathfinding, i enjoyed it very much i have to say.

In most levels you will find much of the same stuff, unlike in blood money where in almost every mission you will have to take a different approach, you really had to !!search!! to complete a mission.

The searching you had in blood money has been placed into absolution in the form of challenges, wich adds a certain amount of replayability and it is pretty ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing awesome to complete them.

So now i can say the real thing that bothered me in absolution was the linear level approach.. you just had a way to follow and when you could get past those guards you completed the level.

It is also pretty frustrating that the disguise doesn't really work, people can see through it pretty easy, in one way i understand, in another i don't because like if there are 2 gardeners and you kill one and you disguise yourself it's ,normal that the other one can see through your disguise,
but if you disguise as a tactical swat officer where you can't see the other ones face then it's not possible that someone can look through it. So that's a bit of a game breaker.

In overall i give the game 8/10 because of the good game if you don't look at the other great games in the franchise, but when you put the game togheter with the franchise then you will see some dark spots on it... in figure of speech

If you are interested in a good game where you have to patient some times but where you can put some decent hours in to enjoy (like i did myself) then this is for you.
If you are a long-run hitman fan then you might not like this game.. (altough there's no reason for it, the game is good)

Thanks you for reading.

reviewText:
I recommend this as a video game. As a Hitman game? Definitely not. Part of what made the older Hitman games so fun was the feeling that YOU were the one coming up with all these methods of killing, thus having a feeling of accomplishment. In this game, all the methods are shown for you in a way that makes them all seem scripted.

Disguising is pretty much useless since it only works provided you have sufficient 'influence', and it drains so quickly you'll just not even want to bother.

Last thing I dislike very much in most games is this fad of giving the player x-ray vision. How can something be at the same time regarded a legitamite element of singleplayer, but hacking in multiplayer? You can try not using it but you always know it's there.

All that aside, if you aren't a long time Hitman fan, you will most probably have fun. I lost interest about 3/4 of the way in.

reviewText:
Hitman: Absolution marks the final nail in the coffin for a once promising franchise; the Hitman: Codename 47.

The game's earliest titles, like Codename 47, and Silent Assassin, were both revolutionary games in the 'free roam assassin' genre, where you had multiple access methods, several scenarios to take out your target with, and a freedom to choose whether to go in hot and deadly and go for the Mass Murderer title, or go in silent and unnoticed and get Silent Assassin. It was up to you, and it had never been done before. The Hitman Franchise was once a blaring success, and many games were sold.
However...As what happens with most developpers who see dollar signs(And you can't blame them, they're only human...Greed comes naturally to us once we taste immeasurable success...We want more). They got off the trails, gave up their outside-the-box thinking strategy, and started to give up on what made Hitman special, and slowly turned it into a shooter. Blood Money was on the verge, with some few points that made it worth buying, but Hitman:Absolution marks the fall of once beautiful franchise.
The game.Is.Complete.and utter.TRASH!

THe once all important Stealth design has been pretty much ignored...Putting on a disguise doesn't really help you with remaining undetected much, as you are fully dependant on your 'Instincts' which is pretty much nothing more than a bar which is represented in a similar fashion to Fantasy games' Mana Pool. It fills when you complete objectives or make tactically accurate moves, and gets drained when you use it...And it is 110% required to use it to slip past guards...Even with a disguise on! I actually found that in more cases than not, it was more beneficial to simply NOT take a disguise, and stay in your suit and tie as long as possible, cause for some reason, guards found a guy in a Mechanic's outfit, outside a mechanic's shop, suspicious enough to shoot at. More so, than a bald ominous guy in a black suit, crouching behind a car...Completely normal Saturday wierdness, right guys?

The 'Going in loud' is also heavily recommended, and it is obvious in just how many tools you're given to kill lots and lots of people...Such as Point Shooting...Use up a chunk of Instinct per target, a total of 4, which you mark, and then hit the Execute key. 47 stands up, and instantly, without any effort, shoots all 4 enemies.
Furthermore...In each mission you have the oppertunity to 'discover' new weapons...Such as revolvers, uzi's m4's, sniper rifles, shotguns, baseballbats, crowbars, crossbows etc. etc. lots of full automatic weapons to really paint an entire map read in blood. Now all this would be cool...If it actually benefitted you...Because for some strange reason, the developpers decided to provide all of these ways to kill people, and all of these cool full automatic weapons to collect, and KEEP THE SILENT ASSASSIN FAVORING SCOREBOARD!...
This means that you will score 'more' points if you IGNORE all of these cool new killing methods/weapons, and go with old school Hitman style gameplay, killing as few people as possible except the target, and getting out undetected, most of the time doing so without having fired a single shot...But if you decide to use these amazing modern-hitman bonus kill methods, you actually LOSE points, and it is completely impossible to go into a Hitman Absolution game, and complete a mission by shooting everything, and getting out with a + sided score count...It will ALWAYS, ALWAYS result in a NEGATIVE scoring if you go in loud...So you are in fact punished for using these new features in Absolution.

The developpers had NO IDEA where they wanted to go with this game...They finally got impatient, took a huge overdose of Fokitol, and released the game with an absolutely BROKEN stealth system, a COMPLETELY unfair scoring system, and a COMPLETELY POINTLESS new set of killing styles that you get PUNISHED for using...

NOT recommended. Jesus Christ guys, let the Hitman franchise die with its dignity intact, stop trying to squeeze the last little bit of green out of its husked corpse already.

reviewText:
Hitman: Absolution. Let me start off by giving the obvious acknowledgement - yes, it is predictably sexist - the strip clubs, the streetwalkers , the PVC-clad, sexy criminal nun gang (yes, I'm not making it up), the old, abhorrent baddies with their 20 something year old hussies dressed in ridiculously revealing outfits, and so on. I'm not going to harp on about it. It's expected.  So now the boring sh*t is out of the way, I can review the game for its quality as a single player game.

The storyline is an extremely gripping, albeit predictable, action-fuelled chase to save a girl (I know, I know) called Victoria, who some baddies have taken for reasons you'll find out during the game. It's a part stealth, part action game, and I really appreciated the fact that you can choose how to go about achieving your objective in the way you want; be it stealth, going in all guns blazing, or setting traps to distract, kill and remove evidence. The controls are a bit fiddly at first, for example, shooting involves using all your mouse buttons, but you can get used to them quite quickly.

The tasks are varied and fun, and some of them made me genuinely laugh out loud (setting a trap so a guy got electrocuted when he urinated on a live wire is one that springs to mind). Agent 47 is a stereotypical badass - chisel jawed, handy with weapons and has an icy stare - but I couldn't help but like him. He was a man of few words, usually delivered just before he shot someboy between the eyes.

The graphics are top notch and some of the scenery is spectacular. The cutscenes are exciting and immersive and using disguises to go into certain areas or bypass guards was particularly fun (did anybody else dress like a scarecrow, or was that just me?) I liked the fact that you had to scout out a building or room and look for ways to carry out your objective, and it wasn't just clear cut. I liked that this game was sometimes really difficult (and I actually ragequit a few times), rather than being linear and obvious. It was well worth the ¬£3  I paid for it during the sales, and I'd absolutely recommend it, particularly if you enjoy stealth games. If you can overlook the usually unecessary titillation in place for the boys, and the occasional cringeworthy scene, this game is really worth a playthrough or two.

Brief Review

Hitman: Absolution is a wickedly smart, darkly enjoyable video game, one that's as generous to players as its protagonist is merciless to his victims. You'll stab, strangle and shoot your way through level after level

Pros and Cons

Pros

Great visuals (Came out 2012 and still stands with some games coming out today 2016)
A lot of improvements to the basic gameplay
Replayable
Missions open-ended
Rewards patience
Stealth gameplay is tense and challenging

Cons

Imperfect disguise system
Linear, anticlimactic sequences
Not enough traditional levels

An Ending

To play Absolution is to view the world through the eyes of a psychopath, a remorseless killer who snuffs out life with the the efficiency, precision and emotion of a fine German automobile

reviewText:
I was considering giving this game a good review because many aspects of this game are good. Music, graphics and voice acting are all there. It has some of the best scripted sequences that I've rarely seen in a game and features a variety of creative ways to kill your target. But where this game screws up big time is in it's level design and specific aspects of its game mechanics.

For the purposes of this review I'd like to like to look at two other stealth franchises which are Batman Arkham and Metal Gear Solid.

The biggest issue in the game is the level design. The first few missions have pretty decent level design. The AI purposefully has weak points that allow you to slip by undetected. You may find certain guards go into a secluded area allowing you to take them out to progress. Challenging but designed in a way which allows the player to slip by if they use caution. I'd say when you get to about the Dexter Industries section of the game all of that goes out of the window.

When you get to the last 2/3rds of the game the level design becomes ridiculous. I've played through hard and purist modes having done a no kill alerts run and let me tell you, unless you use obscure gimmicks there's no way you're beating this game without any alerts. In certain areas there's that many guards all facing each other all the time with visibility on every area that the player needs to go that it makes it absolutly impossible for the player to go stealthy without cheesing the game.

If you look at mgs 1, 2 and 3, even on the highest difficulty in every level the player is given the possibility and abilities to be stealthy and clean. The guards always have certain patterns designed for the player to take advantage of. While still being extremely challenging if you're good you can always remain undetected. In Hitman Absolution it doesn't matter how good you are, unless you resort to specific gimmicks and borderline exploits in many areas, you aren't getting through without being spotted. In the start of many of the levels such as before the fighting match, there are guards that just stand there having a long conversation, forcing the player to sit there impatiently listening each time you try the level. It just interupts the gameplay and it's extremely boring and frustrating.

What are these gimmicks that I refer to? Well in Hitman Absolution you have two ways to deal with guards cleanly, going behind guards and strangling them (which makes all nearby guards look in your direction) and throwing objects to make a guard check it. In many of the later levels the only way to progress is to keep throwing the same object against the wall, strangling the guard that comes to check it over and over until the way is finally clear. You can either do that or use a disguise to just walk past all the enemies without bothering, but that burns all your instinct meter so don't expect to be able to use it all the time. Certain events like the fight with sanchez become ridiculous because the guy with the disguise you need just stands in a spot with about 12 guards all staring at him and doesn't move. So again you have to resort to throwing wrenches at the wall to lure everyone out which takes absolutely ages. It's tedious and boring, but it's the only option for stealthy players.

Batman Arkham, which while being a considerably easier and less challenging game had what Hitman needed badly. A wide variety of non lethal takedowns to deal with enemies. When you're playing hitman, you have to do the same choking animation every single time while tapping X repeatedly. It's depressing. Every now and then you get an animation of 47 hitting someone against a wall but in the end you're doing the exact same takedown over and over again. Playing non lethally in Hitman is the most depressing aspect of the game, but you're punished for killing guards which means the player is constantly trying to play in a boring way. Think of all the different takedowns in batman, like hanging off a ledge and strangling people with your feet, or dropping ontop of them from a great height, or even jumping people out of a vent. Only having the option of choking people out makes the game extremely tedious but you have to do it throughout the entire game.

I cannot stress this enough that the vast majority of this game is throwing wrenches at the wall and waiting for guards to come and check the sound. This is why I found the majority of the game depressing to play and had to give it a bad review. If they had spent more time working on the AI patrols the player wouldn't be forced to constantly use gimmicks to get through the missions. I got through the later missions using an obscure trick where you use your silenced pistol to alert the enemy then run through them because it's the only time you can get through certain guards without killing them. I'm all for challenge, but when it reaches the point where the player is forced to use exploits to progress, it kills the whole point of the game being a challenge. The levels which aren't like this are actually a lot of fun and if the game didn't have such bad level design I'd be giving it a good review right now.

Another thing which is really annoying is the scoring system. You get scored on things such as how many times you were spotted, how many people you killed, did you hide the body.., etc. Yet on certain missions you're forced to kill people and on others there's actually no areas to hide bodies. The scoring system is always telling you you're playing the game wrong, but you don't have a choice because of how badly designed most of the levels are.

In summary the things which killed the game for me: Gameplay interuptions, poorly designed levels, lack of non lethal options, the scoring system constantly criticising you and gimmicky gameplay. I've beaten the game twice and it was mostly not an enjoyable experience. Sometimes it's fun, but most of the time it's frustrating, but not in a good way. I'd say it's worthwhile if you're a Hitman fan since it has some great moments, but I couldn't recommend it to anyone else.  The vast majority of the game is just throwing a wrench and then pressing X repeatedly to strangle a guy out. Extremely boring compared to other stealth games.

This could have been a great game.

reviewText: I always liked Hitman series. I like it so much, that I even prepurchase this game. Initially I was really disappointed. Previous games were made from relatively standalone missions, with background plot. Now there is strong plot connecting all levels. This has many consequences. You cannot choose your gear. Some missions are just linear corridors. There are no contracts. Big disadvantage is missing save function. Yes, there are checkpoints, but they are scarce and repetition of some parts was so frustrating, that sometimes I rather finish the assignment by killing everyone.\n\nSo I was pretty upset, I spent more than 30 euro on game, which I didn't enjoy. Then I realized how to play it. It is no longer pure stealth game. For me, it is more like stealth game with action phases and it works. In linear parts works more aggressive style, while in big open spaces silent assassin style is my choice. Love it. Combat with guns (you can even use human shields) and overall cover system are great. Controls are excellent. Stealth" missions are nicely designed and joy to play. Maps were removed and replaced with instinct. I still miss them

reviewText:
Hitman: Absolution is great.
A great movie.

Like Ghostbusters: The Video Game, it's telling a good story, with awesome characters, great voice acting,
But as a stand-alone Hitman game, it's a shame.
I lost control over my actions, can't decide my killing method, because there isn't any. Can't decide where will I go, because there's only one way. This game is linear as hell.

reviewText:
I'll try to list all things that I've noticed of the game so far

One of the focal points of the series, AI and it's suspicious behaviour towards 47 is done in the cheapest way possible. The AI is at the same time too easy to fool, but too difficult to bypass with disguises, another key element of the previous games.
They will rubber-band you so hard, you cannot approach levels in any previously logical manner. You'll have to adapt to the dumbed-down gameplay. Sometimes you have to distract guards by throwing things at them instead of around them because there are scenes in the game where the AI isn't ready to be distracted by nearby sounds yet.

Theatrics and graphics are used for eye-candy, retrying annoying scenes involving bears and slow-mo may occur. Melee combat is done with QTE's, assassinations completed mostly in cut-scenes. Disguises won't show up in these cutscenes either, by the way.

There's completely arbitrary features like the forced-in scoring system, and the online whatever's. Getting Silent Assassin on each mission is sometimes terrible because it is way too easy, or terrible because the level is built in many sections, and you'll have to try them over and over again to get it exactly right... Or the way the game wants you to complete it. Meaning the tutorial level made it seem that you might not be able to get SA on all levels at all.

The story is good, yet the writing's awful.
Having a vat-grown clone like 47 be more human than humans to safeguard a potentially deadly-in-the-wrong-hands-assassin-girl is a great concept. However there's some lore bringing new unnecessary elements into the plot about 47's past, which are yet another slap in a fan's face. Although It would be more ok if the rest of the game wasn't so bad.

Speaking of faces, Diana's is just blurted out from the start, and seeing as it had been kept a mystery all this time, I feel it would've been more acceptable if there would've been some anticipation to seeing 47's dear handler for the first time through the players' eyes.
Writing tries too hard to make 47 appear more human. 47 is also less intelligent as before, trying to fibre-wire a man thrice his size. Plot device > actions befitting of the character.

Your part in all this will not be to play as 47, but guide him through extremely linear levels, possibly doing some small distractions because hiding in plain sight will never work. Sometimes you'll actually be given the chance to do the assassination yourself instead of a cutscene.

I got this from a midweek madness for 6‚Ç¨'s. And i'll recommend it at that price! It is worth 6‚Ç¨'s to see how a good format of game can be ruined.
My advice for Absolution? If you're like me and've played the previous games, don't be like me, and set your game on easy, say Eff the scoring system" And just blaze through the levels so you can experience the semi-bad story as quickly as possible.
Can't wait to see what'll become of Thief...."

reviewText:
Before anything else, I have never played past Hitman games and my opinions in this review is based only in my experience with Hitman Absolution.

I can understand why the majority of Hitman fans were disappointed with Absolution ‚Äî It is infected by modern day game mechanics. Agent 47 has a Detective Mode-like Instinct that enables him to see behind walls, highlight items, important locations, see the enemy's walking pattern, and enables him to execute a slow-mo auto kill move (mark targets and Agent 47 auto fires). I do understand the reasoning behind the Instinct ability, but it's just too convenient. Fortunately Instinct is limited in higher difficulties. If you're tired of sneaking around, you can always shoot your way through. But that ruins the point of the game and I only use it when my cover was blown and too lazy to restart.

Enemy AI is, most of the time, stupid. When I switched to a different corner, the guard in front of me didn't react. I have to be visible for a few seconds before he notices me. Unlike, say, Metal Gear Solid or Deus Ex Human Revolution, the guards react and take caution when they notice something passed by. In Absolution, they just ignore any oddities they see.

My biggest complaint is the scoring system. They deduct points by taking out enemies, killing civilians, getting spotted, etc. You earn points by disposing bodies, getting specific items, etc. You'll get an overall score after you cleared the level. You get the highest score possible if you go purely stealth, I think. Sure it encourages you be more stealthy, but there are times that I want to get noticed. For example: There's a guard in front and I'm in a guard disguise. A way to eliminate this guard is to lure him to a dark corner. I approached the guard, notices me I'm not one of them, does not attack, 1,350 points deduction, I move away and he follows. I raise my hands, disarmed the guard, knocked him out, and hid his body and gained 135 points. I really like this bait tactic, but the score deduction is discouraging and I ended up tossing stuff around to attract the guards. It's not fun.

On the plus side, game controls are very good. Sticking and navigating Agent 47 to walls is wonky at best, but it's still functional. Stealth take downs and gun combat is good and satisfying. Agent 47 moves like a tank, so don't expect to roll around during firefights. The visuals are very impressive. Everything is so vibrant, detailed and areas with large crowds are a thing to behold. The game has a lot re-playability because of its checklist system. You get bonus points if you get all the weapons in the area, killing enemies with environmental hazards, collecting disguises. Avid item collectors will find this enticing. If collecting is not your thing, you can go to Contracts and beat community-made objectives.

Overall it's an okay stealth game. I like it and most likely I will replay the game again and 100% every level. For die-hard Hitman fans, Absolution is the cancer of the franchise, but to some it's an entertaining game that lets you garrote nuns.

reviewText:
This game TRIES something new with the Hitman formula,but it's HATED by hardcore fans.

Why?
Well,there are different reasons:
-Is isn't an open world;
-You can't choose your weapons;
-How the points system works;
-Instinct;
-They had 6 years of development;
-There are missions where you don't kill/assassinate anyone.

Let's focus on one simple word:ASSASSINATE.
That is the most important reason to explain why most hitman players hate this game.Of course,another one is the instinct that,I have to admit it,it's kinda broken.
I mean,I get it that in one of the missions it's really helpful for escaping because they are working togheter,but how can a person with a mask on the face recognise someone who has a mask on the face.
Pretty stupid,right?

Now,let's talk why this game is INNOVATIVE for Hitman foscusing on three reasons:
-Story:this game actually focuses on the story,there are some holes in it but it's still nice.
Some people say that it's stupid or too sentimental,but IMO it isn't too sentimental,Hitman 2 is more sentimental;
-Instinct:you can call it wallhack,you can call it cheap,but I still think it's something that replaces the lack of a map and could work better if they'll fix it;
-Points system:this works really well IMO to have an idea of your final rating telling you to focus primally on your target and in subduing and hiding the bodies (you can't just take a gun and kill everybody.Ok maybe you can but you'll lose points).

Now that we have talked about the singleplayer,let's talk about the MULTIPLAYER.
No,it isn't deathmatch and all that stuff.
The multiplayer it nails the Hitman formula well and can make hardcore fans happy.
It divides in two categories:People who play the contracts and people who create contracts.
-If you want to play contracts,you'll have to follow the creator's conditions on who to kill,how to kill and what to do.
After the first kill or subduing you'll do on anyone a timer will start,and if you finish the contract before the time ends you'll get additional money.
You can also see your score worldwide and do a challenge on whoever gets the most money;
-If you want to create a contract,you can choose what weapons and disguise should the player start with,you can choose who to kill,how to kill and what conditions the player has to do.
Or you can just choose a gun and shoot anyone without losing points.
Oh,you also get money for every contract completed,and with it you can buy some weapons and upgrades for certain weapons.

BTW,there are also some DLCs,but they are only a bunch of weapons,disguses and unlocks upgrades for some weapons.

Now it remains one more question:should you buy it if you want to introduce yourself to the hitman series or if you are a hitman gamer?
The answer is maybe and yes;maybe because Hitman:Blood Money is a better introduction to Hitman games (but,2006) and yes because I'll say that it's a ok-ish game trying something new and that can be of your liking.
EDIT 16/03/16 The new HITMAN‚Ñ¢  is out and it is a way better Hitman game,so buy that instead unless you want to try a new formula!

So,you want to know my rating?
I'll give it a 8/10 because it has his flaws,gameplay-story affecting and not,but it's something new.

Internet words:
IMO:In my opinion
BTW:By the way

reviewText: This game is one of the smoothest Hitman games I've ever played. Nearly every movement is fluid and natural. Even Blood Money, for the masterpiece that it is, can be a bit clunky at times. The added takedowns and cover system really help you get into that assassin mood. The disguise system is weird but it works, in that guards actually NOTICE that you're not their longtime friend Bill. You can bypass this however by using the Instinct feature, which helps in a multitude of ways. Not only does it show where enemies are at/headed, it also slows down time so you can check the surrounding area without taking up too much in-game time. These features add to the overall efficiency of your kills. After all, that IS what being a hitman is about. The biggest downfall in my opinion was the weak story. It didn't quite feel like it held up as much as previous entries. But while this game is no Blood Money, I can without a doubt say that it is definitely a Hitman game.

reviewText:
For the fans of the series, I fully recommend it. It has a nice storyline, in accordance with the Agent 47 myth. As we are already used, you are the bad guy, but doing the good deed. You can play as a shadow, no one ever noticing you, making most kills look like an accident, or you can take everything head on, making it a nice shooter; but this isn't the case for a Silent Assassin.

The playability is, however, not up to what I would prefer. You have several challenges for each mission, but you cannot achieve them all from the first run, different challenges making you replay the same mission several times (e.g. target assassination in different ways will force to restart, at least from last checkpoint, several times). You also have to perform each mission at least twice as most missions are split in several acts with specific challenges and, to get the highest score multiplier, you need to have already completed all the challenges. This interrupts a lot the story line. My second run through the game, when no longer carrying about challenges/score, but rather do it on my own terms, was, however, a lot of fun.

The introduction of disguises is a nice addition; however, it may be too much. There aren‚Äôt many areas where you can go with your normal black suit/red tie, without raising suspicion; therefore, you will spend most of the game in a different outfit. This made Agent 47 lose his classy look.

The contracts (i.e. multiplayer) are storyline maps, with user created targets and challenges. Most of them are fairly easy and, to some extent, senseless.

But, even so, the game will be fun and will keep you interested enough to come back. If you are fan of the series, you already have it. If you are thinking if it‚Äôs worth to get it, get it. If it‚Äôs on discount, get it anyway.

reviewText:
Ranks on the top of frustrating games. For some good, and some bad reasons. I'll provide only the main reasons.

TL;DR version: Enjoyable stealth game if played on 'normal'. Aggravating (challenging) game on expert/purist (good luck without prior gameplay experience or guides - still doable, but you will get to know levels quite intimately for the number of times you play).

The good:

Very challenging without previous experience. Yea, it was a doozie. Satisfying to have finished the game and there was a reasonable storyline. Lots of quirky characters. Most of which you kill. Yay! Oh, and headshots.


I have never played a Hitman game before and I like playing my games on difficult settings. I did not run purist because that appeared to need some familiarity with the game to play. However, so did Expert. I am glad I played Expert and not Purist. I found it difficult to catch on to what 'deaths' could be setup, what mechanics to use and how they could be used. This isn't necessarily bad... Except that you will probably miss a lot of cool setup deaths such as an individual peeing on a wire you have exposed that leads to their electrocuted demise. It was not intuitive that these types of kills could be done. Decent story. I cursed many times as I was caught in many awkward situations. Also, I did not realize you could upgrade weapons until I finished the game. To have more freedom to 'enjoy' these tidbits in the game I recommend that you play on Normal unless you want the Absolution achievement, then play on Hard,

Headshots.. Headshots are rewarding and make you feel good. 99.9% of occasions 1 headshot = 1 kill. So for those of you who have good accuracy and hate games like GOW for the reason that no person/monster should take a sniper round to the noodle and survive, this game is for you.

The bad:

Melee, lack of checkpoints for higher difficulties, some complete BS detection.

Melee has got to be the most frustrating aspect in the higher difficulties (replaying normal for achievements, melee is a joke because it is so easy in comparison). I did not know for the longest time, until rage level exceeded maximum and I looked up a guide that you are better off watching the animations to know what buttons to press than to actually wait for the QTE event (which gave you a window of what seemed to be less than a second and required inhuman reaction times). FYI: 'Space' if they are attacking you; 'Q' for first hit; 'W' if 47 knocks them in the face backwards; 'E' if 47 knocks them towards the ground.

Checkpoints... Oh dear. Having no familiarity with this game and playing it on Expert lead to a long time of trial and error trying to figure out how the hell to beat some levels. Admittedly I looked up a guide in two circumstances: One of the first levels (can't remember which), and the courthouse. Other than that, no guides... But I can see why people would instantly go to guides after 3...4...10.. 20 failed attempts at a level haha.

Detection.. Silenced weapons are not so silent. I always loved how shooting a target with a silenced weapon would result in being spotted first, then being awarded for the kill (the game awards score based on activity and so it shows, in order, the events that occur and the points associated). Albeit, the circumstances in which I was shooting a silenced weapon (from afar) and being detected were somewhat reasonable, but annoying all the same. So expect to be detected frequenly and die frequently if you play higher difficulties. Especially under circusmtances of choking a guy out only for one of the teammates to 'happen' to turn around and see you. I felt like the game was just trolling me for the number of times people turned around for no reason, not because I made noise, but just because this is Hitman and you need to be demoralized a few times.

There were also many instances where throwing something to distract an individual never worked. The NPC refused to move at all. So you were forced to find some way arouund these stonewall NPCs. On most occasions I emptied a clip into them out of frustration and had to restart the level because A) No checkpoints in expert, and B) I would be detected even if my weapon was silenced.

Alas, time to finish the achievements and move on... Probably never to play this game again.

reviewText: Hitman is a simple concept: someone gives you a target, or targets, and you take them out. The genius of it is the way the designers let you do that. It's not just about deciding whether to sneak past people or get into a gun-fight - it's about slowly tracking the movements of people through large environments and observing the ways you can manipulate them and their surroundings to bring about their downfall. Perhaps you place explosives where you know they'll wander, or maybe you arrive just in time to nudge them over a railing into a deserted alleyway, and often you do all this dressed in borrowed clothes that conceal your identity from all but the most detailed investigation.\n\nHitman: Absolution includes all of that stuff, and on the higher difficulty levels it leaves you to figure a lot of it out on your own. You sneak or roam in disguise through police stations, courthouses, dilapidated mob-run hotels, maize-covered farmland, factories and science labs, teasing out details about your target from overheard conversations and useful objects left on shelves or in poorly guarded rooms. Then you formulate a plan and try to pull it off.

reviewText:
A good story with some great characters and humour, but gameplay is a bit mixed - rigid stealth mechanics with an arcade/consolitis feel. Sometimes you get detected for something that you would get away with in real life and vice-versa. Confusingly, enemy eyesight is matched to their torso instead of the direction their face is looking towards. The challenge is annoyingly increased artificially by over-populating levels with guards. To get past them you take things slowly and memorise their pre-defined patrol routes - which can get a bit tedious. The mechanics have a ‚Äúpuzzle game‚Äù feel to them. There is little room for improvisation. At least you can always go the guns blazing route if stealth gets too annoying. The gameplay does offer good replayability though, if you want to improve your score for each level and beat the scores of your friends.

Levels are on the small side and too linear, but many have nice detail and feel very alive with huge crowds of AI. Some also have funny things and some great easter-eggs. On a technical level though, the graphics are just average (aimed at xbox360 limitations). levels also take unreasonably long to load.

The control scheme feels a bit cumbersome. Shooting mechanics are acceptable, but melee combat is poor - clumsy and harsh quick time events that break the flow of the action. The screen FOV is low by desktop standards. The lack of frequent checkpoints or a manual save system can be annoying if you slip up and have to start from the beginning of a level. Also, your gear and outfit are not saved between levels. Even worse, if you reload a checkpoint, some enemies are alive that you killed before reaching that checkpoint.

So, gameplay is arguably not quite as good as in Blood Money, but I did find the story in Absolution much more entertaining. Other than some minor issues like very slow loading levels, a few bugs and glitches (once an AI spotting me through a floor), the game runs stable.

Overall it is a decent game to get when on sale.

reviewText:
Hitman Absolution is a great stealth game with great production values, the gameplay is a little bit different than previous Hitman titles which lead some fans to dislike this game, if you like Splinter Cell and Metal Gear Solid I think you will enjoy this one quite a bit, if you are looking for something like Blood Money then this is not the game for you.

The game adds a new mechanic called Instinct which serves 2 purposes, to see the location of enemies, and to hide in plain sight to avoid getting your cover blown if you have a disguise (for a limited time depending on difficulty).

The checkpoint system is completely broken, when you die, you respawn at the latest checkpoint but enemies that you have killed, subdued and hidden respawn, this is a non issue if you ignore the checkpoints or if you play in the higher difficulties, Expert and Purist.

Graphics and sound are both pretty good, the game is pretty well optimized, I ran this back in 2012 with an AMD Quad core + GTX 560ti and it ran well on high settings.

Overall I think this game is great if you keep an open mind, just treat it as a different take on the franchise and you'll be fine.

Pros:

- Amazing atmosphere
- Good acting and script
- Contracts mode adds replayability

Cons:

- Not much location variety
- Checkpoint system is completely broken

reviewText:
A successor that feels worthy at first glance, then shows it's little shortcomings when you think things through. A mistake often made. The thinking part, that is.

As usual, if you've come to read this review, you've done some background investigation towards the game itself. So I keep those obvious details short. New aiming system, new gallery of weapons, new ways to interact, etc... You'll have read all this, and your assumption will be right.

The assumption being: This is a stellar improvement over the original. The engine looks beautiful and the weapons handle much, much better.
A lot of my Blood Money gripes have been settled.

But this is no longer a Hitman game like you're used to, in terms of Gameplay. And not always for the better.

In the past installments, you were thrown at a level, a situation if you will. And you had to figure out how to achieve your goal(s), then escape through the way you came. Everything that happened between beginning and end was up to you.

This is no longer the case. Now, you are thrown into a smaller level, where you either need to interact/sabotage something or kill someone, then escape through a designated exit into another section of the mission. Commonly, these are three parts.

As a long-time Hitman fan, this sits uneasy with me and feels less true to the Hitman spirit.
On the flip-side though, this allows new gamers to the Hitman series to easier adopt the spirit and feel of the games. In a way, train them for Blood Money or a successor that returns to the old feel.

Also, while I felt more limited in my playground, I did feel like my curiosity was still stimulated through the methods of murder available to me. The areas are still rife with typical oppertunities, relating to your targets.
You are just deprived of a large part of the exploration, finding these quirks of the targets. More often than not, the 'accident' methods are easily found and the tools are often nearby. You feel less like a detective, but still a little bit.

Storywise, the game may feel like it wants to slowly depart from the original.
47, while still cool as a cucumber most of the time, shows signs of emotion and involvement (well, at least in perspective...).
But when you sit it through, it may start to rather feel like an evolution of the story. In a sense, I think the developers are trying to open doors for the series.

Absolution will be slightly tougher to get into for long time fans. But if they can get over the big changes, you can still get a good time out of it.
For newcomers: This isn't what the Hitman series has always been about, but it's pretty close.

A 25 or 50% off will easily justify a purchase.
If you even remotely think you may like a game like this, you probably will.

reviewText:
Hitman: Absolution pulled off a risky endeavor in removing it's loadout system. It ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• off some long time fans, but the change really makes you appreciate the environment more than ever. The cover system is robust for the most part, the controls are tight and precise for sneaking around.

I finished the game before on Purist mode and I must say, the Instinct system they used in the game is amazing. I could've done without the precision shooting mechanic, but the sound indicator when you're about to be spotted is a great addition to the game. Notice that on harder difficulties you will not have a HUD that indicates who will see you or how close they are in spotting you. If you really want to enjoy the game, I'd suggest you push it on harder difficulties especially if you're a veteran of the previous games. It provides a cinematic experience and your movements will feel really organic - whether it's choking out someone or sneaking from cover to cover.

Absolution's story is lacklustre in comparison to the previous games. While the amazing locations and the voice actors are top notch in providing a great experience, the story's build up does not come close to ANY of the previous games. Though it is nice to see 47 exhibit his human side since Silent Assassin, they seriously wasted it here. Normally I would stop when the story get so horrendous, but they do such a great job of making you feel like a stealthy assassin that I don't mind it all.

I'd highly recommend it for the experience, not for it's story.

reviewText:
Being a fan of the series I was a little skeptical about this game hearing about how some of the fanboys of the series were upset with the direction it went.  Well personally I loved it and thought this games style and artistic design was great.  Yes in a way it is linear and not as open ended as other Hitmans but change can be good and it is with Absolution.

This game features the single player story which is a good lengh over several chapters and different locations.  Then there is contracts mode which you can play with friends and even make your own contract so others can play - this was kind of cool to play.  Contracts are basically assassinations of specific targets with certain goals awarded.

The graphics and art style of the game were great, I love Square Enix's games they seem to have that edge and know how to make games look different - like Kane & Lynch Dog Days and Deus Ex HR for instance.  The voice acting is great - Blake Dexter was my favorite and he is a complete ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.  Hitman himself sounds awesome, the musical score did get a little old for me as it seems to be the same music rehashed and nothing really new.

Combat was decent and enemy AI can be troublesome sometimes the game was never really overly difficult, however I do not play on Purist mode either.  There is a ton of weapons, gadgets and outfits for Htman to collect and the more you collect and the more time you spend involved in the game getting creative the more payback you get with rewards and challenge unlocks.

This was a great game, I highly recommend picking it up as I got it last week on sale with all DLC for about $8 money well spent.  Now I will await the next Hitman or I could play Blood Money again.

reviewText:
Epic story, fantastic gameplay, awesome graphics. A truly remarkable game. The Contracts Mode puts it one step ahead.

Hitman: Absolution, the fifth game of the Hitman franchise, has so much to be told about. For the first time we are presented a movie-like story line that shows 47 has feelings and emotions (who would have guessed?) making the game feel very immersive. Characters are very well developed, the voice acting is just perfect and the entire plot will get you so angry at some characters that you will enjoy, with a big evil smile on your face, ending the life of those hateful characters however you wish.

The gameplay feels smooth and easy to understand just like in the other Hitman games despite a few changes here and there. Now you can hide behind walls and crouch behind boxes like you were never able to. The graphis, of course, were greatly improved and reached a level that amazes anyone. The lighting is great, the phisics engine is very realistic and the AI behaviour seems more immersive too.

The levels of the game, on the other hand, feel like a small corridor that only goes in one direction. The freedom you used to have in the other games is just gone, pretty much like saving (which was replaced by useless checkpoint saves that won't save a thing but that position), picking your weapons before the missions and purchasing and customizing your friendly guns. Why? Why this huge step back in the franchise?

But! Contracts mode was introduced allowing you to play the missions of the game as you want, chose up to 3 targets you want and kill them however, whatever with and whenever you see fit. Then the mission will be saved and posted for everyone to play it and the other players will have to complete it as you did so that they can earn the most out of it. You can create competitions with other people for those contracts and completing them earns you money you can spend on upgrades, disguises and weapons for Contracts mode only.

In my personal opinion and considering how awesome Hitman: Blood Money was, my rating for Hitman: Absolution is only a 7/10. Yes, the story is amazing, but it feels you have no freedom at all. Yes, the graphics, gameplay and Contracts mode are too, but there is so much that could be improved concerning the little things from other games.

Perhaps, the next Hitman will be as hardcore as previous Hitman games and as badass looking and story-wise awesome as Absolution. If this is true I'm sure a 10/10 is in order.

Pros:
- Fun game
- Semi-open world
- Decent stealth mechanics
- Offers a few different ways to complete missions
- Both stealth and run & gun game styles are fun
- Good replay value
- Decent story
- Excellent graphics and production quality

8.8/10 Well worth playing if you like stealth-based games.  Fun to stealth your way through until you get caught, then fight the rest of the level, then replay the level stealthing all the way through, then replaying again using different strategies and disguises to succeed.

reviewText:
If you like the Hitman series, you won't enjoy this. Granted, it retains values of stealth games but at the expense of a working formula. I'm not opposed to change (Unless it's quicktime events, tsk tsk Square Enix) but this drastic shift in gameplay did not transition well with this title.

This game has a lot of redeeming qualities, but, a lot of detriments. If you're willing to compromise and deal with it, so be it, have at it.

Other than those nitpicks, I must say, there are better Hitman games and better Stealth games. This is an awkward love child of traditional stealth and the Hitman formula but without the satifaction of either.

(Side note: There are a lot of bugs including the AI, detection/disguise system, and more. You have been warned)

reviewText:
Fifth Hitman in the series, following a completely new path in comparison to previous installments. Without spoiling anything for those that haven't yet played the game - you are not just leading assassination after assassination. Its different. Agent 47's role isn't just being a Hitman, its also to protect.

As much as Absolution takes a completely different slant on the normally-expected storyline, I hold high praise for IO Interactive & Square Enix (Publisher & Developer). In simple terms, it worked brilliantly. For future titles, I would be disappointed if this was now normality. As a one-off, Absolution places you in different situations then Agent 47 is used to. The silent assassin now requires to look after not just himself, and must think on his feet quickly to the change in environments. Do expect linearity in missions.

A new and slightly frustrating feature in this game, although realistic, is the enhanced disguise function. Normally Agent 47 would be able to wear any type of uniform to slip past guards/security with ease.. not anymore! The AI isn't as thick as what it once was. Now you have the detection meter, so you could be wearing a police officer uniform - walk towards a police officer on duty - and get immediately alerted as a target. Time to be careful! You might be wearing the correct uniform, but people know who is on duty and who isn't. Therefore through this new feature, you can use your stealth meter to hide" your face

reviewText:
Fifth Hitman in the series, following a completely new path in comparison to previous installments. Without spoiling anything for those that haven't yet played the game - you are not just leading assassination after assassination. Its different. Agent 47's role isn't just being a Hitman, its also to protect.

As much as Absolution takes a completely different slant on the normally-expected storyline, I hold high praise for IO Interactive & Square Enix (Publisher & Developer). In simple terms, it worked brilliantly. For future titles, I would be disappointed if this was now normality. As a one-off, Absolution places you in different situations then Agent 47 is used to. The silent assassin now requires to look after not just himself, and must think on his feet quickly to the change in environments. Do expect linearity in missions.

A new and slightly frustrating feature in this game, although realistic, is the enhanced disguise function. Normally Agent 47 would be able to wear any type of uniform to slip past guards/security with ease.. not anymore! The AI isn't as thick as what it once was. Now you have the detection meter, so you could be wearing a police officer uniform - walk towards a police officer on duty - and get immediately alerted as a target. Time to be careful! You might be wearing the correct uniform, but people know who is on duty and who isn't. Therefore through this new feature, you can use your stealth meter to hide" your face

reviewText: I'm a huge fan of stealth-action games, which is why I've rated Batman: AC and Deus Ex: HR so highly, but this game seems to be the exception. I don't mean to imply that the stealth in this game is of a lower quality than the two I've listed, in fact it's probably on par with them, but the real issue I have with this game is the way it approaches gameplay in general. In each level, you have a score at the top of your screen. Points are gained for completing specific challenges and lost for doing things wrong. While it's possible to ignore the score, Hitman focuses very heavily on score being integral to your experience with the game. The challenges are sometimes easy and sometimes difficult, but it's often impossible to complete multiple in a single run through a level. As a result, you'll find yourself replaying the level over and over again in an attempt to complete the challenges. And then, one time, you accidentally do something majorly wrong, like killing an enemy in plain sight (I SWEAR THAT GUY DIDN'T SEE ME!!!") and you lose the majority of the points you've spent an hour-and-a-half cultivating. Well

reviewText:
An absolutely amazing game and a well done sequel to Blood Money. The people at IO Interactive decided to raise the stakes by making Agent 47 fight the Agency itself. As usual, the levels are varied and they were all meticulously designed. 47 traverses through various locales and all this is presented to us beautifully. I remember Blood Money being a beautiful game but Absolution upped all this - this game certainly stands out in its genre.

I expected this considering the companies behind the game. After all, high production value can easily yield the necessary results. However, it is not enough to make a game with an interesting story or gameplay and this is where Absolution excels.

For those of you who are new to the franchise: in Hitman you control an assassin whose job - on each level - is to eliminate someone. Stealth should be the preference as while running and gunning is also an option (but makes the game significantly more difficult) picking the silent run method gives a much higher satisfaction. Enemies' clothing can be picked up and disguise is important to get through various parts of each level.

A change to previous installments is that some sequences are specifically action oriented or more linear. Yet, core and hardcore elements are still there. Also, predicting the routes enemies do can be done with the introduction of the so-called Instinct Mode". I would say that this Hitman is easier on a normal difficulty than its predecessors but one can always go for the additional challenge by picking another difficulty.

All in all
date: an excellent follow-up to the franchise and
hoursPlayed: highly recommended to the fans as well as to the newcomers."

the game, while possessing of decent visuals, little to no bugs, and a good system of movement has one massive flaw, it utterley removes the choice to play as you see fit.
the constant points system, that rewards certan obscure and pointless behaviour (such as picking up a beer bottle) and punishes killing non targets (by detucting points) really crushes the casual enjoyment for me.

while this may not seem like a big deal, for those who are like me in the respect that they like to carve a bloody path, or kill a few guards who are in the way as opposed to waiting thme out will likely be utterley dissapointed, as such behaviour will result in zero XP and thus halt progression in it's steps (by this i refer to the leveling up system).

while i can see the arguement for rewarding accurate, sharp and stealthy gameplay styles i want to play my games in the style that i deem fit, and when the game becomes unplayable as a result (not attached to the AI reacting to your behaviour) then i feel that i a hve been let down greatly.
games are about choices, and this game offers only one if you want to succeed

if you are a fan of extreme stealth and zero wanton killing then this game is quite likely for you.
if you like to shoot someone OTHER than your end target then i would steer clear of this one.

reviewText:
I can't quite put my finger on it, but I really, really enjoyed this game. It is completely different in many ways from say - Hitman: Blood Money (which you should definitely play first if you haven't), but I believe most of these changes were either necessary or in good taste. The graphics are a huge improvement, the soundtrack is fantastic, the dialogues are well written and there are tons of goofy easter eggs in the grim setting of Absolution.

Just one little thing. Checkpoints are bugged. There is no other way to play this game than on purist (the highest difficulty).
Picking this difficulty will eliminate checkpoints (that are broken anyway), remove ESP and make the game more pleasant overall. Anyone who gives this game a bad review was probably playing on normal, and complaining about the broken checkpoints or built-in wallhack.

No really, playing on low difficulty is like playing as Charles Xavier from the X-men. The only thing missing is mind control and psychic beams.


Definitely buy this game after you've finished blood money, and Absolution is on sale. Just remember this: there are no glitches on the highest difficulty.

SO
Get it when its on sale sometime, and pray the next title goes back to Hitman's origins but keeps the better gameplay

reviewText: Hitman: Absolution does nothing by halves. When the game is good, it's fantastic and borderline brilliant. But when the game is BAD, woah boy, is it BAD. Missions are generally broken down into two different types; being given targets to assassinate by any means necessary, and Metal Gear Solid-esque sneaking through larger levels to get to the exit. The former can be absolutely stellar; you have to plan takedowns of other targets to get disguises to get close enough to your target (preferably without getting caught, as the best laid plans will understandably get torn asunder if someone sees you moving a body), and are then given a variety of methods to take your mark out, ranging from doing it personally with a gun or garotte wire, or, my personal favourite, using various parts of the environment to set up accidental kills"
date: like framing your target so he gets shot by police
recommended: setting a live wire to where they urinate in an alley in order to electrocute them
hoursPlayed: or less subtle methods like causing a crane's hook to come undone and crushing them with its contents.\n\nUnfortunately
voteText: where the game falls apart is in the long stealth sections that make up the rest of the game. There's very few checkpoints

The Agency reforms under Agent Benjamin Travis; Travis assigns 47 to kill Diana and bring Victoria, a teenage girl in her care, to the Agency.
