reviewText:
I'll be upfront: I went into this game expecting, essentially, an upgraded, spotlessly polished, prettified Blood Money. For me, Blood Money was the epitome of Hitman. Why would they change what was the ultimate expression of the sandbox assassination? There are lots of reasons I could speculate on, but for anyone considering this game, know this: It is nothing like Blood Money. Further disclaimer: I suck at this game. Sorry about that. So, this review is from the point of view of Easy and Normal modes.
That said, on to the actual review, then. Wall of text incoming, I take this fairly seriously, because well hey, everyone needs a hobby.

I'm going to look at this game two ways: as a generic stealth game, and as a Hitman game.

As a stealth game, it's above average, good even. The usual illogical fallicies aside (i.e. hiding behind/rolling between cover in a disguise is the most effective means of transversing an area, despite it's suspicious as hell), it's still satisfying. In comparison to Blood Money where disguises were the be-all-end-all, IO revised the disguise system to where enemies who are dressed like you are will see through the disguise (they supposedly know who they work with, after all), while other people will simply assume you're supposed to be there (provided you have the appropraite disguise). For me, this was at first annoying, and then I realized its brilliance and logic, and adjusted accordingly. It does, however, need tuning rather badly, but it is most certainly workable. The biggest issue I have with the stealth system as a whole is the Instinct" resource. It's consumed to blend in with your chosen disguise (and use a "mark and execute"-style ability in combat)

47, however soon discovers that nothing (as usual) is what it seems and is soon sent off to take care of .. a person. A kid at that.

reviewText:
This is a tough game to recommend. Hitman games are always judged harshly, because the concept is just so simple and wonderful: You are a silent assassin in an impeccable suit, contracted to kill various people around the world using a piano wire, high power sniper rifles, explosives, poison... whatever seems best suited for the job. It's perfect, but the truth is the games themselves never live up to the potential.

This one looks great and has some interesting setups, but most of the levels are just too small. Hitman usually comes down to a Groundhog Day to make the perfect kill: you explore the level, your possible weapons, disguises, distractions, exits, you experiment and restart... Restart after restart you figure out the patrol routes and your optimal path. But in Absolution, the most of the levels are just to small to really take in and enjoy. It forces you to replay it and try out new things to get the highest score, but it's just a hollow retread of what you've seen before.

Absolution isn't impressive storywise either, with lots of things not making scence and Agent 47 doing tons of stupid things when you aren't in control.

Overall, Hitman: Absolution has its moments, but they are few and far between, it could have been a lot better.

reviewText:
After completing a few mission of Hitman: Absolution I get the feeling it was never completed to the level the developers were reaching for. However, I really enjoyed the story of this game, the game play is primarily a stealth...I want to say puzzle game.
Let me explain, there are usually multiple routes in each level for you to reach your goal, and figuring out each route an how to execute it (no pun intended) can be a bit tricky. Every mission you encounter has typically one of two objectives; reach the exit undetected, kill the target in an inventive/uninventive way and escape undetected. This of course sounds linear in level design, and in some instances it is.
Regardless I think this game is worth the money you spend on it. The developers gave a good deal of thought on how this character would  complete his objective realistically. NPC behavior though predictable never left me ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• off at its stupidity or god like behavior you see in many NPC behavior packages(damn NPC has aimbot ). The in game  textures are nice, and the outdoor environments were pretty enough to make me want to explore areas before completing a mission . Protagonist and antagonist character models are well done with NPCs getting the unfortunate short stick in the looks department.
The voice acting for this game is generally pretty good and the voices do seem to fit the character models spot on. However, there are rare occasions were the mouths don't sync up to the words (still better than almost any final fantasy created after 7).
Again, all in all, I found this game to be a good addition to the Hitman franchise only lacking a PvP mode for general fun

reviewText:
Absolution was the first Hitman game I played so i can't really compare it to anything. Graphically this game is incredible, although cutscenes and the game look noticably different. Story is okay but I didn't really care about it in this game I just wanted to stealthily murder people. I first had this on PS3 and i played it how I prefer to play stealth games, kill most people unnoticed (the panther style in SC: Blacklist basicly). However the game only rewards you for playing it how the game wants you to: only kill targets (preferably by accicedent) and never get seen, which is the way I try to play it on PC. It's just a bit annoying seeing that -100 or whatever in the top left whenever you kill a non-target.

Now we move on to the disguise system. Basicly for those who don't know, in this game you can kill people, once a person is dead or knocked out you can take their clothes. But the way it works is that if you get too close to a person with the same disguise then they will start to notice you, unless you use instinct (which also let's you see people through walls and stuff but runs out quite fast). This is the problem. For example, not every single police officer is going to know the face of every other police officer in America. But the owner of a mansion dosen't notice if his chef has a different face because they don't wear the same clothes.

The game gives you enough options as to how to approach most of the missions, with Chinatown being one of the best missions in the game. In the Chinatown missions (there are more than one) there are so many different ways to approach them. The more linear missions are okay but not as good as they could've been.

OVERALL:
-Graphics : 10/10
-Story : 5/10
-Gameplay : 7/10
Final Score : 7.5  (also happens to be the average)

reviewText: I wish I could recommend this, I really do. I tried so hard to like it. I'm a fan of the series, but this just doesn't hit the spot. Aside from the story being throwaway crap (not that story matters in a Hitman game), the gameplay is sorely lacking. Far too many missions have you trying to inflltrate or escape somewhere, and there are far too few assassination contracts. The few that are there show promise, but the disguise system is pretty broken, and there's often only one or two approaches that can succeed, due to the extremely rigid AI. You'll either be checking walkthroughs or restarting far more frequently than you'd like.\n\nMaybe worth a look in a cheap sale ($20 or less), but I couldn't bring myself to finish it. At about 40 hours in (almost halfway - not because it's long, but because that's how often you'll be restarting if you want to be stealthy), I had to admit to myself that I just wasn't having fun, as much as I wanted to like it.

reviewText:
Bourne's Review
-------------------------
Overall: 7/10
-------------------------
Plot: 5/10
Gameplay: 9/10
Graphics: 8/10
-------------------------
Plot: Very weak. This is (To my knowledge) the first Hitman game where they really attempted to give more depth to the protagonist, 47's, character. And it..... left much to be desired. The overall plot within the game wasn't absolutely terrible, but very predictable after awhile and the ending was extremely anti climatic and quite frankly, stupid. This is mainly where the game falls flat on it's face for me, had the plot actually had some interesting points to it I might have really really enjoyed this game more, but it didn't. The characters were very colorful, but I never felt connected with them. That being said, I did very much enjoy the game overall, mainly because of the gameplay itself, where Hitman games really shine.
-------------------------
Gameplay: The gameplay in both Hitman games I've played (Blood Money and obviously Absolution) have been exceptional (At least in my opinion) delivering exceptionally open ended levels with set targets or objectives, and plenty of optional objectives and challanges. To condense it,  a typical mission has at least a solid dozen ways to kill your target, ranging from a wide variety of methods. From poisoning, sniping, dropping objects on, pushing off cliffs, blowing up, planting explosives, shooting with a giant whale harpoon, disguising as a decorative samurai and stabbing as they walk by, spiking cocaine, dropping a car on them, embedding an axe in their skull, to electrocuting them, or setting up a gas explosion; the options are virtually limiteless. There are multiple ways to approach a target as well, from taking a maintenance uniform as disguise, to running in guns blazing, sneaking along back alleys, blending with a crowd, or disguising as a scarecrow and creeping through a cornfield. And of course, general killing and mayhem is super fun as well, tossing guys out windows, strangling, throwing a knife into their head, and then silently disposing of their body in a leaf mulcher - this Hitman game makes it just plain fun to kill people. And since that was, of course, the objective of the game, to kill targets, it nailed it. Combat and gameplay in Absolution is superb.
There is a very nice point system built into Absolution as well - the game automatically tracks your poitns (Based on how silent you are, headshots, signature kills, if you were spotted, etc.) and uploads those scores at the end of each level to their leaderboards. Then, if any of your Steam friends play that level themselves, they'll see your highscore displayed at the top when they begin, giving them a little incentive to try and beat your score, and vice versa. Some people do not like the points system but I thought it was a good way to encourage stealth and I found myself specifically reloading levels to try and beat my friends score.
It is also worth noting that Absolution can be a VERY, VERY hard game, if you want it to be. There are 6 difficulty settings in the game - the highest difficulty offers you no assistance from outside intel, much more enemies per level, much harder objectives, and overall increases the difficulty to near impossible, presenting even the most hardcore Hitman fans with crazy challanges.
Sidenote: If you have played Absolution and liked it, or are at all interested in Hitman games, I would recommend also checking out Hitman: Blood Money
-------------------------
Graphics: The graphics in Absolution are very very nice, and in many ways unique. The developers use of glare, bloom, and FOV make the game a bit harder to run for some, but pay off in very deep graphics. I did notice that the FOV and everything else combined, didn't present the most crisp graphics, but it did provide a very atmospheric feel to it, and certainly felt as if it fit the game. The colors were especially rich and vibrant. The settings in the game varied greatly, some missions were in noisey crowds in Chinatown, others in nightclubs, some in hospitals or secret facilities, and others in the dusty streets of small towns. These varieties in settings provided a constant changing backdrop to your murders and always presents new ways to kill.
-------------------------
Replayable? - Yes, the game has so many options of how to kill, as well as extremely hard challanges such as finishing everything silently, or 'Suit Only' (Meaning you complete everything without taking a single disguise) and offers enticing options for replaying missions.
-------------------------
Bottom Line Recommendation: Hitman Absolution delivers very fun gameplay and a great challange on most missions, and while the plot felt weak, I would recommend the game.

reviewText:
When Hitman Absolution was announced, people were afraid it would be another victim of the recent modernization of old video games that negatively affected games like Syndicate and XCOM. Well, that did affect Absolution, but it definitely didn't ruin it.

This time around, there's been a lot more effort put into the plot. It's the best story in the series and I must say that the ending is also great and very satisfying, no loose ends, some sequel bait but nothing too big. The characters are great, great voice acting, all good! The fact that the plot is a bigger thing does make the game A LOT more linear but nothing too bad.

The graphics are pretty good and very well optimized. I managed to run it on a stable 60 fps all the way through on an outdated laptop and the game still looks great after you lower the graphics. The pre-rendered cutscenes are a bit weird though, it would have looked better if they did everything in-engine.

The gameplay is also pretty good. Shooting and moving feels way better than in the previous games, everything feels much more polished and smooth. The stealth is very satisfying, specially when you manage to pull off those awesome no-kill runs, the full-stealth runs and the poisoned your coffee" assassinations. There are still a bunch of ways for you to kill your targets and it definitely still feels like a Hitman game. Unfortunately

reviewText:
Absolution was the first Hitman game I played so i can't really compare it to anything. Graphically this game is incredible, although cutscenes and the game look noticably different. Story is okay but I didn't really care about it in this game I just wanted to stealthily murder people. I first had this on PS3 and i played it how I prefer to play stealth games, kill most people unnoticed (the panther style in SC: Blacklist basicly). However the game only rewards you for playing it how the game wants you to: only kill targets (preferably by accicedent) and never get seen, which is the way I try to play it on PC. It's just a bit annoying seeing that -100 or whatever in the top left whenever you kill a non-target.

Now we move on to the disguise system. Basicly for those who don't know, in this game you can kill people, once a person is dead or knocked out you can take their clothes. But the way it works is that if you get too close to a person with the same disguise then they will start to notice you, unless you use instinct (which also let's you see people through walls and stuff but runs out quite fast). This is the problem. For example, not every single police officer is going to know the face of every other police officer in America. But the owner of a mansion dosen't notice if his chef has a different face because they don't wear the same clothes.

The game gives you enough options as to how to approach most of the missions, with Chinatown being one of the best missions in the game. In the Chinatown missions (there are more than one) there are so many different ways to approach them. The more linear missions are okay but not as good as they could've been.

OVERALL:
-Graphics : 10/10
-Story : 5/10
-Gameplay : 7/10
Final Score : 7.5  (also happens to be the average)

reviewText:
Hitman: Absolution is a fantastic game! It has interesting story, visuals, characters as well as gameplay.

There are two modes in this game, the single player mode named absolution and contract mode.

The single player mode features a great story in which we play as agent 47 to carry out assassinations on targets in beautiful and immersive environmental set pieces. There are around 20 levels which takes place mostly in Chigaco and Hope town. Levels are broken down into several sections in order to make gameplay much more digestible as they are served in bite-size portions.

Players are also scored for almost every mission and with the inclusion of the leaderboard, it makes the game highly replayable for me as I would want to replay every mission in order to beat the scores of my friends and be at the top of the leaderboards.

Lists of collectables in each level are also featured at the end which enable the player to know which collectables they have collected and the ones that they have not. This give players who are completionist an additional task of replaying that particular level and finding the rest of the collectables.

Although you are able to complete each mission on a variety of ways, this game highly emphasizes on stealth as you are given more points for being stealthy such as hiding bodies and remaining unseen, while going in guns blazing would give you a low score as you are given negative points for every NPC you killed that is not the targets.


Contract mode enable players to create their own contracts by marking any target in any of the single player levels and playing it in order to prove that it can be completed before other players are able to attempt their contracts. This help extends the game replayability as I am able to play through other player's contract and attempt to kill their mark target in the same fashion that they did and vice versa. Completing contracts award players with money which they could use to unlock disguises, weapons or weapon parts.


The only major gripe in this game would be that it could be extremely frustrating and challenging to play through in the higher difficulty levels such as expert and purist mode. There are also minor bugs in this game such as character's clipping issues with clothing which is very obvious in a level called blackwater park with the character Layla as you can see some patches of the clothes clipping into the skin.


To summarise:
PROS:
+Great Gameplay
+Great Visuals
+Memorable Characters
+High replayability
+Cool looking disguises!
+Contract Mode
+Great voice acting
+Score System and leaderboard

CONS:
-Bugs like Clipping issues
-Ridiculously challenging in higher difficulty level

Overall I would give this game a 8/10 which is a fantastic game!

reviewText:
In my opinion it's a step away from the other classic Hitman games.
They ditched the perfect formula Blood Money had with upgrading/choosing your items at the mission intermissions.

More importantly the gameplay seems needlessly..... well.. impossible.
Impossible to be sneaky rather. Later levels seemingly have unavoidable bottle-necks to where you will end up shooting your way out of a bad situation 90% of the time.

the rating system (Specialist, Veteran, Professional, Silent Assassin) isn't very clear. 47 is naked without his signature items for a good portion of the game. The detection system seems to have a mind of its own sometimes....

That being said. Its a decent stealth game. It looks decent as far as graphics go, but they still took some shortcuts. I'm glad i bought it on a steam sale as it is definetely not worth the full price.

Its the usual one playthrough game as acquiring money/upgrades is completely irrelevant.

the create-a-contract mode is a complete fluke as well. There is absolutely no point to it...

I had a lot more fun playing the sniper challange that came with the game then the actual game itself.... a complete letdown and disgrace to passed Hitman games...

reviewText:
Hitman: Absolution is a fantastic game! It has interesting story, visuals, characters as well as gameplay.

There are two modes in this game, the single player mode named absolution and contract mode.

The single player mode features a great story in which we play as agent 47 to carry out assassinations on targets in beautiful and immersive environmental set pieces. There are around 20 levels which takes place mostly in Chigaco and Hope town. Levels are broken down into several sections in order to make gameplay much more digestible as they are served in bite-size portions.

Players are also scored for almost every mission and with the inclusion of the leaderboard, it makes the game highly replayable for me as I would want to replay every mission in order to beat the scores of my friends and be at the top of the leaderboards.

Lists of collectables in each level are also featured at the end which enable the player to know which collectables they have collected and the ones that they have not. This give players who are completionist an additional task of replaying that particular level and finding the rest of the collectables.

Although you are able to complete each mission on a variety of ways, this game highly emphasizes on stealth as you are given more points for being stealthy such as hiding bodies and remaining unseen, while going in guns blazing would give you a low score as you are given negative points for every NPC you killed that is not the targets.


Contract mode enable players to create their own contracts by marking any target in any of the single player levels and playing it in order to prove that it can be completed before other players are able to attempt their contracts. This help extends the game replayability as I am able to play through other player's contract and attempt to kill their mark target in the same fashion that they did and vice versa. Completing contracts award players with money which they could use to unlock disguises, weapons or weapon parts.


The only major gripe in this game would be that it could be extremely frustrating and challenging to play through in the higher difficulty levels such as expert and purist mode. There are also minor bugs in this game such as character's clipping issues with clothing which is very obvious in a level called blackwater park with the character Layla as you can see some patches of the clothes clipping into the skin.


To summarise:
PROS:
+Great Gameplay
+Great Visuals
+Memorable Characters
+High replayability
+Cool looking disguises!
+Contract Mode
+Great voice acting
+Score System and leaderboard

CONS:
-Bugs like Clipping issues
-Ridiculously challenging in higher difficulty level

Overall I would give this game a 8/10 which is a fantastic game!

reviewText:
Bourne's Review
-------------------------
Overall: 7/10
-------------------------
Plot: 5/10
Gameplay: 9/10
Graphics: 8/10
-------------------------
Plot: Very weak. This is (To my knowledge) the first Hitman game where they really attempted to give more depth to the protagonist, 47's, character. And it..... left much to be desired. The overall plot within the game wasn't absolutely terrible, but very predictable after awhile and the ending was extremely anti climatic and quite frankly, stupid. This is mainly where the game falls flat on it's face for me, had the plot actually had some interesting points to it I might have really really enjoyed this game more, but it didn't. The characters were very colorful, but I never felt connected with them. That being said, I did very much enjoy the game overall, mainly because of the gameplay itself, where Hitman games really shine.
-------------------------
Gameplay: The gameplay in both Hitman games I've played (Blood Money and obviously Absolution) have been exceptional (At least in my opinion) delivering exceptionally open ended levels with set targets or objectives, and plenty of optional objectives and challanges. To condense it,  a typical mission has at least a solid dozen ways to kill your target, ranging from a wide variety of methods. From poisoning, sniping, dropping objects on, pushing off cliffs, blowing up, planting explosives, shooting with a giant whale harpoon, disguising as a decorative samurai and stabbing as they walk by, spiking cocaine, dropping a car on them, embedding an axe in their skull, to electrocuting them, or setting up a gas explosion; the options are virtually limiteless. There are multiple ways to approach a target as well, from taking a maintenance uniform as disguise, to running in guns blazing, sneaking along back alleys, blending with a crowd, or disguising as a scarecrow and creeping through a cornfield. And of course, general killing and mayhem is super fun as well, tossing guys out windows, strangling, throwing a knife into their head, and then silently disposing of their body in a leaf mulcher - this Hitman game makes it just plain fun to kill people. And since that was, of course, the objective of the game, to kill targets, it nailed it. Combat and gameplay in Absolution is superb.
There is a very nice point system built into Absolution as well - the game automatically tracks your poitns (Based on how silent you are, headshots, signature kills, if you were spotted, etc.) and uploads those scores at the end of each level to their leaderboards. Then, if any of your Steam friends play that level themselves, they'll see your highscore displayed at the top when they begin, giving them a little incentive to try and beat your score, and vice versa. Some people do not like the points system but I thought it was a good way to encourage stealth and I found myself specifically reloading levels to try and beat my friends score.
It is also worth noting that Absolution can be a VERY, VERY hard game, if you want it to be. There are 6 difficulty settings in the game - the highest difficulty offers you no assistance from outside intel, much more enemies per level, much harder objectives, and overall increases the difficulty to near impossible, presenting even the most hardcore Hitman fans with crazy challanges.
Sidenote: If you have played Absolution and liked it, or are at all interested in Hitman games, I would recommend also checking out Hitman: Blood Money
-------------------------
Graphics: The graphics in Absolution are very very nice, and in many ways unique. The developers use of glare, bloom, and FOV make the game a bit harder to run for some, but pay off in very deep graphics. I did notice that the FOV and everything else combined, didn't present the most crisp graphics, but it did provide a very atmospheric feel to it, and certainly felt as if it fit the game. The colors were especially rich and vibrant. The settings in the game varied greatly, some missions were in noisey crowds in Chinatown, others in nightclubs, some in hospitals or secret facilities, and others in the dusty streets of small towns. These varieties in settings provided a constant changing backdrop to your murders and always presents new ways to kill.
-------------------------
Replayable? - Yes, the game has so many options of how to kill, as well as extremely hard challanges such as finishing everything silently, or 'Suit Only' (Meaning you complete everything without taking a single disguise) and offers enticing options for replaying missions.
-------------------------
Bottom Line Recommendation: Hitman Absolution delivers very fun gameplay and a great challange on most missions, and while the plot felt weak, I would recommend the game.

reviewText:
Initially I didn't like the game at all. After the first couple missions I got that hang of how the game wanted me to play and I stopped expecting it to work like Blood Money. Absolution is a different beast altogether, and you have to acknowledge that in order to actually enjoy the game.

I feel that Blood Money gave you more options when completing a mission. Blood Money is mechanically the better game, in my opinion.

Absolution has new mechanics like instinct, but I don't think it's a necessary addition. While it's possible for the player to just ignore instinct, it feels as though the map design was done with being able to see through walls in mind.

Stealth in absolution is forgiving, to say the least. You have a small window between when the enemy spots you and when they come after you. This small window isn't very small. You can basically sneak from point to point uncontested despite being in clear view half the time. There is less planning than there was in Blood Money. In Blood Money you had to wait and figure out the enemy's patrol route before executing your path. Getting spotted was more deadly.

Absolution emphasizes stealth less. I hate that games these days are being made easier and easier in the stealth department. Especially for the Hitman series: this is a stealth game, why take away game mechanics that encourage it?

Still enjoyed the game immensely though, in the end.

---
If you enjoyed Blood Money, I think you'll also enjoy Absolution IF and only IF you don't expect it to be like Blood Money.

reviewText:
The mess that is Absolution left me constantly thinking of it as a modern day Trespasser. I.e., a game great in ideas and, most importantly, potential, a potential that goes unfulfilled following really bad design decisions that basically break the game. It's good and bad. Some moments you'll love it, and others you'll want to tear your eyes out while berating the developers for What in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ed hell were they thinking implementing this ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ed disguise system?

At times, depending on the level, it plays out perfectly, stealth, the environment and quick thinking playing important roles, but then there are those moments when you have no choice but to rejoice in the irritating instinct system unless you--maybe--look up the one and only way of beating a level perfectly on purist difficulty on YouTube--if it exists.

So that's it: A back-and-forth developmental gesture that leaves you loving it one level and then tearing your hair out in frustration the next. As weird as it is to say, I expected more from the developers of the ludicrously underappreciated Kane & Lynch 2.
